loans.name: Edda

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 53-year-old Edda M. from Mbeya. She is married with three children, between the ages of 14 and 20. Edda has been running a cafe since 1992. A local restaurant or café, also known as a "Mama Lishe" in Tanzania, usually consists of a rough wooden table and some long, wooden benches. The food is all local: rice, ugali (a hot sticky dough, made from maize flour), plantain (a cooked savoury banana), served with beans, vegetables, meat, and a variety of sauces.

Edda works at the business for 12 hours per day, 6 days per week. Edda currently earns about US$ 120 from her business. She is requesting a loan of US$ 175 in order to purchase additional rice, cooking oil, charcoal, and wheat flour. In the future, she plans to renovate her venue. Edda thanks you for your support!

•

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback micro-finance facility.

Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase additional rice, cooking oil, charcoal, and wheat flour for her little restaurant

loans.name: Rukia Mohamed's Sea Cliff B Group

texts.en:
Rukia M., age 38, is married with 4 children, ages 18, 13, 10 and 8. Rukia has a business of selling traditional clothes such as vitenge (Swahili fabrics) and kangas (Swahili sarongs). She started this business 20 years ago! She works daily from 7:00 AM until 4:00 PM and is able to earn a monthly profit of about $167.

This will be Rukia's second loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the first loan to increase her stock and has since paid the loan back successfully. She intends to use this new loan for the same purpose.

Rukia will share this loan with her subgroup, Sea Cliff B. The group has 7 members. The members of the group hold each other accountable in paying back their loans. In the picture, Rukia is in the back, second from the left.

loans.use: To increase stock of clothes

loans.name: Maria Dolores

texts.es: La señora María Dolores habita en el barrio la primavera, barrio ubicado en la capital Managua, tiene la edad de 36 años, se encuentra casada con el señor Bernardo Reyes, quien se desempeña como mecánico juntos tienen dos hijos los cuales son estudiantes, la familia de doña María habita en casa de familiares, donde una de las aspiraciones de ella es poder trabajar con mucho esfuerzo para que en un futuro tener su casa propia. Actualmente dona María dolores se desempeña  como comerciante de cosméticos y lotería, teniendo 4 anos de realizar esta actividad, iniciando la misma con prestamos de bancos comunales, por tanto ella sigue necesitando de mas financiamiento para poder invertir en su negocio, solicitando un crédito de C$ 15,000 a un plazo de 12 meses, para  poderlo invertir en capital de trabajo y así reforzar mas su negocio, ya que una de sus  expectativas a futuro es poder establecer su propio local, donde pueda vender cada uno de los productos que actualmente comercializa.
texts.en:
Señora María Dolores lives in the La Primavera neighborhood in the capital of Managua. She is 36, married to Señor Bernardo Reyes, who is a mechanic, with two children who are in school. They live with relatives, and one of her aspirations is to work hard so that in the future she can have her own home. Currently Doña María Dolores sells cosmetics and lottery tickets, which she has done for 4 years, starting with loans from communal banks. Nevertheless, she needs more financing in order to invest in her business. She is requesting a loan of $775 over 12 months, to invest in working capital to strengthen her business. A hope for the future is to be able to open her own shop, where she can sell all of the products that she now markets.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Sanford, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy more cosmetics inventory and lottery tickets

loans.name: Giovanna  Del Rosario

texts.es: La señora Giovanna habita en el barrio Laureles Sur, barrio ubicado en la capital Managua, tiene la edad de 41 años, se encuentra casada con el señor José Benito Pérez, quien se desempeña como mecánico, juntos tienen dos hijos de 4 y 16 anos de edad, los cuales están estudiando. Doña Giovanna posee un pequeño negocio en su casa de habitación de venta de cosméticos y repostería, el cual lo inicio hace 9 años con dinero propio, actualmente ella junto con su marido trabajan con mucho esfuerzo para darle una buena educación a sus hijos y prestarle una casa digna para que vivan tranquilos, por tanto esta solicitando el apoyo de financiamiento para la reparación del baño de su casa  , donde requiere la cantidad de C$ 12,000 aun plazo de 9 meses, de esta forma poder ir mejorando poco a poco  su casa y también las instalaciones de su negocio, donde en un futuro ella aspira poder hacer crecer su negocio para seguir apoyando a su familia.
texts.en:
Giovanna lives in the Laureles South neighborhood located in the capital city Managua. She is 41 years old and married to Mr. José Benito Pérez, who works as a mechanic. Together they have two children ages 4 and 16 who are both students. Giovanna has a small business in her home from which she sells cosmetics and baked goods/pastries. She started the business nine years ago with her own money and now she and her husband are working hard to provide a good education to their children and to give them a good home where they can live peacefully. For this reason she is requesting financial support for the repair of the bathroom in her home which requires the amount of $625US for the period of nine months. In this manner she will be able to improve her home little by little as well as equip her business. In the future she hopes to be able to make her business grow inn order to keep supporting her family.

Translated from Spanish by Kristy Placido, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy construction materials and repair the bathroom.

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 25-year-old Asha I. from Mbeya. She is married and has two children, ages one and six. Asha has been running a tailoring business since 2005. She works at the business for eight hours per day, six days per week and is assisted by her husband. Asha currently earns about $50 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of $250 USD to purchase cloth. In the future, she plans to open another business. Asha thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through micro-leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that is allows clients to use equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase cloth

loans.name: Juma Alfani's Sea Cliff C Group

texts.en:
Juma A., age 26, is married with a 1-year-old child. Juma is a carpenter, a business he started back in 2001. He works daily from 8:00 AM until 6:00 PM and is able to earn a monthly profit of about $250.

This will be Juma's second loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. He used the first loan to increase his business and has since paid the loan back successfully. He intends to use this new loan to purchase raw materials so he can build more beds, cabinets, and dressing tables.

Juma will share this loan with his subgroup, Sea Cliff C. The group has 7 members. The members of the group hold each other accountable in paying back their loans. In the picture, Juma is the only male.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials to build more products

loans.name: Tunsume

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 30-year-old Tunsume F. from Mbeya. She is single with 1 child who is 3 years old. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting 2 dependents because they are schooling in the area. Tunsume has been running a used clothing business since 2006. She works at the business for 12 hours per day, 6 days per week, and is assisted by her children. Tunsume currently earns about $70 from her business. She is requesting a loan of $400 in order to purchase additional stock of cloth. In the future, she plans to increase the quantity and range of the business.

Tunsume thanks you for your support!

Used clothing sales business: Secondhand clothes journey across the oceans from America and Europe, and are then washed, ironed, and sold in bulk by wholesalers in Tanzania to retailers who then re-wash and re-iron them for sale on the streets and in the surrounding towns and villages. These clothes are becoming increasingly popular, especially amongst the younger generation, because of their low cost and the general appeal of anything modern.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock of clothing

loans.name: Rebeca

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 39-year-old Rebeca K. from Mbeya. She is divorced with 2 children, aged 9 and 12. Rebeca K. has been running a cloth and café business since 1998. A local restaurant or café in Tanzania usually consists of a rough wooden table and some long, wooden benches. The food is all local: rice, ugali (a hot sticky dough, made from maize flour), plantain (a cooked savory banana), all served with beans, vegetables, meat, and a variety of sauces.

She works at the business for 12 hours per day, 6 days per week, and is assisted by her brother and sister. Rebeca currently earns about $300 from her business. She is requesting a loan of $400 in order to purchase wheat flour, chairs, and a table for the café and to buy additional cloth for the cloth business. In the future, she plans to open another business.

Rebeca thanks you for your support!

loans.use: To purchase wheat flour, chairs, and a table for the café and to buy additional cloth for the cloth business

loans.name: Edina

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 53-year-old Edina I. from Mbeya. She is widowed with two children, 10 and 15. Edina has been running a farming business since 2005, buying maize from farmers and selling it in the market at a higher price. She works at the business 12 hours per day, 6 days per week. Edina currently earns about 170 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 250 USD in order to purchase additional stocks of maize. In the future, she plans to increase the quantity and range of her stock.

Edina thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback micro-finance facility.

Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of maize

loans.name: Christina

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 28-year-old Christina M. from Mbeya. She is married and has two children, ages 2 and 8. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting one other dependant because her parents can not take care of her. Christina has been running a cloth material and tailoring business since 2003. She works at the business for eight hours a day, six days a week and is assisted by her husband. Christina currently earns about $300 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of $400 USD to purchase an additional sewing machine and additional stocks of cloth. Christina thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through micro-leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that is allows clients to use equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase a sewing machine and cloth

loans.name: Halima

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 50-year-old Halima N. from mbeya. She is a widow with five children between the ages of 19 and 32. Since 2005, Halima has been running a bar where she sells soda, beer and pure drinking water. She works at the business 12 hours per day, 7 days per week. Her bar is a good place to relax with a beer if you manage to finish work early on a Friday afternoon. You can relax on a plastic chair under a tree with a local beer in your hand and the aroma of roasting mishikaki (kebabs made on an open fire) wafting around you, and talk to everyone who happens to wander by.

Halima currently earns about 100USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 250USD in order to purchase additional stocks of beer, water, and soda. She plans to increase both the quantity and range of the stock. Halima thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, so they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that is allows clients to use their equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of beer, water, and soda.

loans.name: Tatyana

texts.en:
Tatyana supports herself entirely from her little clothing sales business which she has operated for the last twelve years. Divorced with one grown son, she lives by herself and works hard to earn enough money to meet her needs. Her monthly income is typically around $500. 

Tatyana has taken several loans from Nadiya Ukraine and has proven to be a very responsible client, making each of her payments on time. The loans she received have had a big impact on her business and she is excited to be able to use additional funding to increase her sales even further. She has requested a loan for 6300 Grivnas, $1200, which will enable her to purchase more of the quality clothing items that she offers. This available capital will give Tatyana the resources and flexibility to buy inventory in greater volume, allowing her to have more time and energy to focus on expanding her business.

loans.use: To increase assorted inventory

loans.name: Ludmila

texts.en:
Seven years ago Ludmila found her niche at the Covered Market in Zaporozhye when she opened her small business selling seeds, plant protection chemicals, footwear, shoe care items, etc. Over the years Ludmila has acquired solid experience selling retail products. Through her determination and hard work she has been able to build a loyal customer base, which is not a small feat considering she has many competitors. Ludmila's business has led to a stable profit of $600 a month from more than $2,000 of invested inventory.  

Today, Ludmila is asking for a loan of 3000 Grivnas, $575, to help increase her working capital. She understands that new selections will help her satisfy the needs of her customers. Her goal is to see each customer leave with what they like and need. Ludmila is excited about the opportunity to see her business grow and change. She is also very delighted to earn additional funds so that she will be able to provide for her family.

loans.use: To increase working capital for winter season

loans.name: Galina

texts.en:
A married mother raising two daughters, Galina depends on her clothing sales business to make ends meet. She retired from her previous work because the salary was not enough for her to live on. Eight years ago, she decided to start her own business in order to supplement her income. Galina has gained valuable experience over the years and has established a good reputation as a business owner. She understands her product very well and is always fair to her customers and co-vendors in the market. 

Galina has also been a good client with Nadiya Ukraine, having repaid all loans to the company. She has requested an additional loan of 2500 Grivnas, $500, to purchase new clothing inventory for her business. In the future she hopes to make enough extra income so that she can put aside some savings. We are happy for this opportunity to further assist Galina as she works to support her family of four.

loans.use: To purchase assorted inventory

loans.name: Alla

texts.en:
Alla works in a very successful women's clothing business. She operates a sales location where she offers a selection of trendy jean apparel that is always in demand. Alla's business has a long history. She was able to start this venture 14 years ago and since that time her business has done quite well. She has around $1000 of gross income each month. Alla is quite an entrepreneur and we are happy that she has chosen to apply her talents in a business that helps women be even prettier.

Alla has requested an additional loan of 3000 Grivnas, $575, to give her more working capital to use in her business. It will be exciting to see how Alla's enterprise will continue to grow in the future as she's off to even greater success. The loan will help Alla develop her business and support her family of three. 

Note: this is a short term seasonal loan that will be repaid in two months.

loans.use: To meet the demand this season

loans.name: Mariya

texts.en:
Mariya is an entrepreneur from Vinogradovo. She is in business selling electric lamps and lamp stands in one of the units of a local mall. Mariya started this business about 7 years ago. Currently, she has about $12,000 in merchandise. Her monthly gross income is about $1,000. 

Mariya's business is characterized by stability and consistent expansion of inventory. She admits that financial assistance from Nadiya Ukraine has added a lot to the success of her trade. Mariya has an entrepreneurial mindset. It helps her press on and never stop when she is faced with another challenge. This time she is requesting a 2000 Grivna loan, $400, to increase her assorted inventory and have higher sales as a result.

loans.use: To increase assortment of inventory

loans.name: Delia

texts.en:
Delia Q. V. is a member of the community bank Juanito in Ayacucho, Perú. Delia spends most of her time making purses, bags, dolls, and baskets out of cloth.

Delia will use her loan of 1600 soles to pay a part of her rent and purchase more fabric to make her gifts. Delia dreams of having her own business--a small store where she can sell her artisan work. Since her rent is very expensive, she has been saving to purchase her own home so she can put her savings into her land instead of someone else's pocket.

loans.use: To pay a part of her rent and purchase more fabric to make gifts to sell.

loans.name: Marita Luz

texts.en:
Marita Luz E. S. is an unmarried mother of 2, aged 7 and 1 years old. She lives in Ayacucho, Perú and is a member of the community bank, Juanito, in Ayacucho, Perú. Marta spends her time cooking common Peruvian dishes including caldo de gallina, a soup made with chicken and broth and salchipapa, which is a dish made with sausage and potatoes.

She will invest her loan of 1000 soles into her restaurant by purchasing rice, potatoes, sausage, spices, oil, and chicken. Currently, her cousin lives in Italy, Marta’s goal is to move with her children to Italy. She dreams of being able to provide her children with a better education and to open a restaurant with her cousin.

loans.use: She will invest her loan of 1000 soles into her restaurant by purchasing rice, potatoes, sausage, spices, oil, and chicken.

loans.name: Banco Maranatha Group

texts.en:
Banco Maranatha is a group of 15 entrepreneurs who are looking for their third loan from Esperanza International. With their first two loans, all the members were able to start their own businesses. They are now looking to expand their businesses and really start improving their lives. So far everyone in this group has had some success and has been able to pay all the loan fees on time.

Marie L. is the representative of this group, chosen because she is a great leader and a hard-working woman. She is the mother of 3 children. Her children are her life, and she wants nothing more than to provide them with a comfortable life. Marie started a small business producing and selling food. Her dream is to live with her family in their own house and to be able to travel someday. She can't wait for this next loan because she feels that it will really help her business go to the next level.

On behalf of Marie, the rest of the group, and Esperanza International: thank you for your support!

loans.use: Buy products to produce and sell food

loans.name: Rosa

texts.en:
Rosa Q. is an unmarried mother of two, ages 5 and 3. She is a member of FINCA Perú in the community bank, Juanito. Rosa works during the day selling candies while walking up and down the main streets of Ayacucho. Additionally, she cleans bathrooms in the evenings.

With her loan of 1000 soles, she will invest into her candy business. Rosa is currently saving to reach her goals of owning her own larger house and her own store where she can sell candies and groceries.

loans.use: With her loan of 1000 soles, she will invest into her candy business.

loans.name: Bocar

texts.fr: Bocar D. est un menuisier expérimenté. Il esr marié et grâce à son activité il entretien bien sa famille. Il fait un chiffres d'affaires de 15000 à 20000 fcfa par jour. Ce crédit lui a permis de renforcer ses activités.
texts.en:
Bocar D. is an experience cabinet maker. He is married and, thanks to his work, he is providing nicely for his family. His sale figures come to 15,000 to 20,000 francs CFA per day. This loan would enable him to boost his business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Carpentry

loans.name: Alejandra Sandra

texts.en:
Alejandra Sandra P. D. is married and lives with her 3 children, aged 2, 4, and 6. She is a member of the community bank Juanito and FINCA Perú. Alejandra weaves belts and purses, and also offers weaving lessons to her neighbors and friends.

With her loan of 2000 soles, Alejandra will invest in her business by purchasing more yarn and materials to make her products. Currently selling her artisan work from her home, Alejandra dreams of being able to use her savings to open her own small store and sell her work from there.

loans.use: To purchase more yarn and materials for weaving belts and purses.

loans.name: Gloria Amanda

texts.en:
Gloria Amanda R. C. is a single mom of two children, aged 13 and 9. Gloria is a member of the community bank, Juanito. She supports her family by selling cheese and potatoes. Every Saturday and Sunday, Gloria travels to the local markets to sell her goods. Monday through Friday, Gloria travels to Lima to package food to export to Spain.

She will use her loan of 2000 soles ($675 USD) to purchase bus tickets for her weekly trips to Lima, and also to purchase cheese and potatoes. Currently, Gloria is saving in hopes of purchasing her own land to build her own house and to purchase a car to travel back and forth to Lima.

loans.use: To buy bus tickets, cheese, and potatoes

loans.name: Marina

texts.en:
Marina H. Y. is married with three children over the age of eighteen. Marina is a member of the community bank Emprendedoras, which means "enterprisers" in Spanish. Marina sells groceries every day from her home.

She will use her loan of 400 soles (~$150 USD) to invest in her business by purchasing vegetables, fruits, various meats and cheeses, refreshments, cookies, and candies. With her savings, Marina's goal is to continue improving her grocery sales. She is also helping her children pay for their education at the University. She dreams that they will continue with their education and become professionals. .

loans.use: To purchase vegetables, fruits, various meats and cheeses, refreshments, cookies, and candies for her grocery business.

loans.name: Mareme

texts.fr: La cinquantaine passée, mareme est une femme mariée mére de plusieurs enfants.Depuis son jeune age ,elle  a fait de la vente du lait caillé son principale activité.Tout les jours,les habitants du quartier se rendent chez elle pour achater leur lait.Le lait est gardé dans des refrigirateurs à la maison .Pour faire face à la forte demande elle va avec le pret acheter un refrigirateur  pour augmenter   ses capacités de stockage.
texts.en:
Mareme K., over 50 years of age, is married and has several children. From a young age, she has earned her living selling curdled milk. Every day, the local inhabitants go to her house to buy their milk. The milk is kept in refrigerators in the house. In order to keep up with high demand, she is going to use this loan to buy a refrigerator to increase her storage capacity.

Translated from French by Alison Dent, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy a refrigerator

loans.name: Trinidad

texts.en:
Trinidad A. S. is a member of the community bank Emprendedoras, which means "entrepreneurs" in Spanish. She is a widow with five children; all of her children are currently in school. Trinidad sells plants from her home. She also sets up a small stand daily from 11am-2 pm where she sells grains, wheat, and puca picante (a common dish in Ayacucho made with potatoes, rice, and chicken or sausage) for immediate consumption.

With her loan of 800 soles (~$275 USD), Trinidad will invest in her businesses by purchasing plants, chicken, potatoes, and more grains. The savings she has accumulated since becoming a FINCA member will be used to help her children with their education. Purchasing land and building a home is another of Trinidad's dreams.

loans.use: To purchase plants, chicken, potatoes and more grains to support her food- and plant-sales.

loans.name: Rudy Roxana

texts.en:
Rudy Roxana R. H. lives with her mother-in-law, her husband, and their seven year old son. Rudy Roxana is a member of the community bank Emprendedoras, which means "entrepreneurs" in Spanish. Rudy Roxana and her husband have an animal farm where they raise lambs and pigs to sell. Their animals give birth and then the babies are kept for about 8-10 months until they are sold. She and her sister-in-law also sell salchipollo daily, which is a common dish consisting of sausage, rice, and chicken.

With her loan of 400 soles (~$150 USD), Rudy Roxana will invest in her businesses by purchasing oil, potatoes, and more livestock. With her savings she would like to build her own home where she can live with just her husband and son.

loans.use: To purchase oil, potatoes, and additional livestock to raise and sell.

loans.name: Teresa Del Socorro

texts.es: Doña Teresa está solicitando su crédito para invertirlo en mejora de su vivienda (construcción de una habitación), tiene tres hijos: el mayor de 12 años estudia su quinto grado, la otra estudia tercer grado y  el niño menor de 4 añitos. Teresa con los créditos anteriores ha ido poco a poco mejorando su vivienda,  además no solo se dedica a enseñar sino que tambien es una mujer que trabaja de la mano con su marido en la parcela cultivando diversos cultivos para asi mejorar las condiciones de vida de ella y su familia;  cabe mencionar que ella es una mujer que inició dando clase de manera voluntaria en una comarca a 3 horas de camino montada a caballo y así fue como adquirio una plaza pagada por el estado, Teresa ha sido un ejemplo de mujer ya que ayudó a su comunidad llevando el pan de la enseñanza a los niños campesinos de su comarca
texts.en:
Teresa is requesting this loan in order to invest it in her home (construction of a room). She has three children: the oldest is 12 years old and is in the fifth grade, her daughter is in third grade, and the younger son is 4 years old. With her previous loans Teresa has been improving her home little by little. Besides being a teacher she is also a woman who works side by side with her husband on the property cultivating various crops so that she can improve the living conditions of her family. It deserves mentioning that she is a woman who began giving classes as a volunteer in a region three hours from her home by horseback and from there she was able to obtain a paid position (paid by the government). Teresa has been an example of a woman who has helped her community, bringing the gift of education to the rural children of her region.

Translated from Spanish by Kristy Placido, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Construction of a room.

loans.name: Isabela

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 29-year-old Isabela M. from Mbeya. She is married and has three children between the ages of one and five. Isabela owns and operates a small stall from which she sells roasted fish. She buys fresh fish daily from local fishermen as they come in with their morning catch, and then roasts and sells these fish. Fish are plentiful in the waters around the city and is a staple of the local Tanzanian diet. She is an enterprising micro-entrepreneur who is taking advantage of a local need to make monthly profits of $240. She works at the business for 12 hours a day, 7 days a week. She is requesting a loan of $400 USD to purchase more fish. Isabella thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through micro-leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase fish

loans.name: Paula Imelda

texts.en:
Paula Imelda G. M. is a member of the community bank Emprededoras, which means "entrepreneurs" in Spanish. She lives in Ayacucho with her husband and their two children, both of whom are in school. She supports her family by working for the state as a doctor's technical assistant. Additionally, when she receives requests, she makes quilts for babies and beds, and she weaves belts and purses.

With her loan of 1000 soles (~$350 USD), Paula will invest in her textile business by purchasing yarn and materials for her artisan work. With her savings, she dreams of opening her own store, where she will be able to sell her quilts, belts, and purses.

loans.use: To purchase yarn and materials for her artisan work.

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria L. Q. is married and has three children. Her eldest son is 27 years old and a cook; her daughter is 23 years old and a nurse; and her youngest son, 16, is in school. Victoria is a member of the community bank Morenita II. On a weekly basis, Victoria travels to nearby cities to purchase grains and corn to bring back to Ayacucho to sell at the market.

With her loan of 2100 soles (~$700 USD) Victoria will invest in her business by purchasing additional corn and grains. The money will also help pay for her travel expenditures to buy the goods. With her savings, her goal is to continue to improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase corn and grains and to help pay for her travel expenditures to buy these goods.

loans.name: Rosa Sonia

texts.en:
Rosa Sonia C. D. is married with three children, aged eighteen, fourteen, and seven. She is a member of the community bank Morenita II and runs her own printing business. At her store, customers can have prints made from the computer, have copies made, create spiral books for presentations, and use the telephone.

Rosa will invest her loan of 3000 soles (~$1000 USD) into her business by purchasing materials such as ink for her printers, as well as by buying copy machines and paper. With her savings, her goal is to purchase modern machines for her store and to provide great service to her customers.

loans.use: To purchase ink for her printers, as well as to buy modern copy machines and paper supplies for her printing store.

loans.name: Evelina

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 43-year-old Evelina K. from Mbeya. She is married with four children, between the ages of 12 and 23. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting two dependants because they are orphans.

Evelina has been running a fish-selling business since 2003. She buys fish from fishermen, brings them to town, and sells them. Fish is plentiful in the waters around the city and is a staple of the local Tanzanian diet.She works at the business 12 hours per day, 7 days per week and is assisted by her children.

Evelina currently earns about 60 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 250 USD in order to purchase fish. In the future, she plans to expand the business.

Evelina thanks you for your support!

• SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback micro-finance facility.

Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase fish for re-sale

loans.name: Maribel

texts.es: La Señora Maribel esta solicitando su crédito, para invertirlo en mejora de su vivienda,  con este prestamo piensa repellar y ponerle el piso a su vivienda, labora como docente en el Nerpe Deyling Olivas Betancurt, cuenta con la ayuda de su marido quien es agricultor y quien cual obtiene los productos basicos del consumo Nicaraguense, tiene 2 hijos, la niña de 13 años estudia su quinto grado y el niño menor de 7 años estudia su segundo grado en la escuelita de la colonia la Esperanza en el municipio de Nueva Guinea; Maribel  es una mujer de escasos recursos economicos que ha luchado  con su marido por ir mejorando su vivienda, han luchado por ir mejorandola poco apoco para tener un hogar digno, que cumpla con las condiciones que la familia necesita y su deseo es que sus hijos estudien para ser alguien en la vida y cumplir con sus sueños.
texts.en:
Maribel is requesting a loan in order to invest in the improvement of her home. With this loan she plans to plaster and put a floor in her home. She works as an educator/docent at the Nerpe Deyling Olivas Betancurt. She also relies on her husband who is a farmer and who is the one who obtains the basic Nicaraguan products. She has two children, a girl of 13 years in the 5th grade and a younger boy of 7 years who is in 2nd grade. Maribel is a woman of few economic resources who has struggled along with her husband to improve her home. They have struggled to improve it little by little in order to have a proper home that will meet the needs of their family. Her wish is that her children will study so that they can be someone in life and to realize their dreams.

Translated from Spanish by Kristy Placido, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To plaster and to add a floor to her home.

loans.name: Nelly

texts.en:
Nelly D. S. is a member of the community bank Fe, which means "Faith" in Spanish. Living with her husband and two children, Nelly runs her own police apparel store.

With her loan of 900 soles (~$300 USD) she will invest in her business by purchasing police uniforms, patches for uniforms, and boots. She places her orders and then travels to Lima to pick up her products. Nelly is currently saving her money so that she can buy a larger store. She thinks her current store is too small to hold all of her available products as well as new items that she plans to add in the future.

loans.use: To purchase police uniforms, patches for uniforms, and boots for her uniform supply store.

loans.name: Gerardina

texts.en:
Gerardina B. D. H. is a member of the community bank, Fe, which means "Faith" in Spanish. She, her husband, and their four children live in Ayacucho. At the open market where residents and visitors of Ayacucho come to purchase a variety of items, you can find Gerardina selling various meats.

Her loan of 750 soles ($250 USD) will be used to buy more meat including chicken and pork and also to buy wine. Gerardina's goal for her business is to maintain her business and continue working until she no longer able to work.

loans.use: To buy meat and wine

loans.name: Negwako

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 20 year old Negwako M. from Mbeya. She is married with a one-year-old child. Negwako has been running a traditional African cloth business since 2003. Her business is purchasing Traditional African cloth in whole sale and selling them in retail. She works at the business for 12 hours per day, 7 days per week and is assisted by one employee and her sister. Negwako currently earns about $100USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of $350USD in order to purchase additional stock of traditional African cloth. In the future, she plans to open another business. Negwako thanks you for your support!

Negwako has established a store that sells traditional clothing worn by Tanzanian women, called kanga and vitenge. The kanga is a piece of printed cotton fabric often with a border along all four sides. It is printed using the silkscreen method with its pattern in frames. Kitenge (the Swahili plural is vitenge) is a cotton fabric with wax print, printed by using rotary printing machines. Kitenge is a communicating textile - the various colors, patterns, writings and symbols represent moods, feelings, cultures, and traditions of native African people.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Lending. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a lending microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microlending is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: Negwako would like to purchase additional stock of traditional African cloth to resell.

loans.name: Tarcila

texts.en:
Tarcila R. D. Q. is a member of the community bank Obreras, which means "worker" in Spanish. She and her husband live in Ayacucho and have been working together every Monday through Saturday at their glass store since they were married over 30 years ago.

Tarcila will use her loan of 2600 soles (~$850 USD) to purchase mirrors, glass, wood, and aluminum for their store. With her savings Tarcila plans to buy something useful for herself, like a car. A car will make it easier for Tarcila to purchase products from wholesalers and deliver products to her customers.

loans.use: To purchase mirrors, glass, wood, and aluminum for her glass store.

loans.name: Happy

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 27-year-old Happy R. from Mbeya. She is married and has two children, ages 4 and 7. Happy has established a store that sells traditional clothing called kanga and vitenge, which is worn by Tanzanian women. The kanga is a piece of printed cotton fabric often with a border along all four sides. It is printed using the silkscreen method with its pattern in frames. Kitenge (the Swahili plural is vitenge) is a cotton fabric with wax print, printed by using rotary printing machines. Kitenge is a communicating textile - the various colors, patterns, writings and symbols represent moods, feelings, cultures, and traditions of native African people. 

Happy buys the clothing wholesale and resells it at retail prices. She works at the business for 12 hours a day, 6 days a week and is assisted by her husband. She currently earns about $300 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of $400 USD to purchase additional stock of kanga and vitenge. Happy thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through micro-leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase kanga and vitenge

loans.name: Salome

texts.en:
Salome A. L. is a member of community bank Obreras, which means "worker" in Spanish. With the help of her three children, she works as a distributor and supervisor at a local gas station in Ayacucho called Repsol. Frequently, Salome makes requests to a distributor in Lima to refill her pumps, and a truck comes to her store the following day to fill her order.

The loan of 2000 soles (~$675 USD) will be invested in her business by purchasing more gas to attend to her customers' needs. Salome is currently saving her money to be able to pay the bills she has acquired from her recent diagnosis of osteoporosis. She does not want to leave these bills for her children and wants to take care of them while she still can.

loans.use: To purchase more gas to attend to her customers' needs.

loans.name: Cheikh

texts.fr: Marié pere de famille,cheikh s 'active dans la vente des pieces de rehange pour vehicule depuis années .Les principaux produits qu' il vende sont des huilles moteur ,les joints,liquide pour frein,et autres accessoires pour vehicule.Avec le pret il va renforcer son activité en achettant des quantites importante de marchandises.
texts.en:
Cheikh is married and the father of a family. He has been active in selling spare parts for vehicles for years. The principal products he sells are motor oil, gaskets, brake fluid, and other vehicular accessories. With this loan, he is going to bolster his business by buying sizable amounts of goods.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Anna

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 38-year-old Anna M. from Mbeya. She is widowed and has three children between the ages of 14 and 20. Anna has been selling rice since 2007. She buys rice from farmers and sells it in towns. She works at the business for eight hours a day, six days a week and is assisted by one employee. Anna currently earns about $300 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of $325 USD to purchase additional rice. Anna thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through micro-leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase rice.

loans.name: Abdoulaye

texts.fr: ABDOULAYE M. EST UN COORDONNIER AU MARCHE MOUSSANTE DE THIES DEPUIS SON ENFANCE. AVEC LE PRET IL COMPTE S'APPROVISIONNER EN CUIVRE ET D'AUTRES PRODUITS POUR LA FABRICATION DE CHAUSSURES.
texts.en:
Since childhood Abdoulaye M. has been a shoemaker in Thies’ Moussante market. With this loan he plans to stock up on leather and other products for the manufacture of shoes.

Translated from French by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of materials

loans.name: Upendo

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 32-year-old Upendo M. from Mbeya. She is single with two children, aged 5 and 10. Upendo has been running a crop business since 2005. Her business is to purchase crops from farmers and sell them in the market. She works at the business for 10 hours per day, 6 days per week and is assisted by her sister. Upendo currently earns about $300USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of $400USD in order to purchase additional stock of crops. In the future, she plans to expand business. Upendo thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Lending. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a lending microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microlending is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: Upendo would like to purchase additional stock of crops.

loans.name: Sabina

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 44-year-old Sabina B. from Mbeya. She is married with four children between the ages of 14 and 24. She is also responsible for supporting two dependants because they are orphans. Sabina has been running a grocery since 2007 and her business is doing well. She works at the business for 12 hours per day, 6 days per week. Sabina currently earns about $200USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of $400USD in order to purchase rice, sugar, salt, cooking oil, kerosene, etc. for her store. In the future, she plans to expand business. Sabina thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Lending. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a lending microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microlending is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: Sabina would like to purchase rice, sugar, salt, cooking oil, kerosene, etc., to resell at her store.

loans.name: Butusyo

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 41-year-old Butusyo K.from Mbeya. She is married and has five children between the ages of 15 and 26. Butusyo has been running a duka (a neighborhood shop where common household and grocery items are sold) since 2000. Her business is doing well. She is assisted by her brother. Currently, she earns about $300 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of $400 USD to purchase additional rice, soda, cooking oil, and sugar. Butusyo thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through micro-leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase grocery supplies

loans.name: Aicha

texts.fr: AICHA A. EST UNE MONITRICE AU PDEF DE JAMMI XALEYI. PARALELLEMENT, ELLE S'ACTIVE DANS LE CMMERCE D'HABITS PRETS A PORTER ET DE TISSUS DEPUIS +10 ANS.
texts.en:
Aicha A. is an aide at the PDEF of Jammi Xaleyi. Besides that work, she has been selling ready-to-wear and cloth for more than 10 years.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of ready-to-wear and cloth for re-sale

loans.name: Bocar

texts.fr: M.D. est un menuisier en bois  trés experimenté installé dans le Quartier de Ouakam  a Dakar ; il a  une clientéle trés fidéle du fait de la qualite de son travail et des meubles vendus . Avec le developpement de ses activités ; il sollicite un crédit pour renforcer son fonds de roulement.
texts.en:
Mr. D. is a very experienced cabinet maker in the Ouakam District. He has very loyal customers. For the development of his business, he is requesting a loan to bolster his working capital.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Bolster his working capital

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 45-year-old Lucy S. from Mbeya. She is widowed with four children between the ages of 15 and 27. Lucy has been running a phamacy since 1993 and business is good. Lucy currently earns about $200USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of $400USD in order to purchase additional medicine. In the future, she plans to open another business. Lucy thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Lending. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a lending microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microlending is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: Lucy would like to purchase additional medicine for her pharmacy.

loans.name: Mouhamadou

texts.fr: MOUHAMADOU K. EST UN COMMERCANT DE DATTES, COLAS DEPUIS SON ENFANCE. IL EST MARIE ET PERE DE 3 ENFANTS.IL HABITE AU QUARTIER MOUSSANTE DE THIES.
texts.en:
MOUHAMADOU K. has been a merchant trading in dates and cola nuts since he was a child. He is married and the father of three. He lives in the MOUSSANTE district of THIES.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cola nuts, dates... ...

loans.name: Filomena

texts.en:
Filomena N. D. G. is a member of Obreras community bank ("obreras" means "worker" in Spanish). A widow with 7 professional children, Filomena sells grains and potatoes at the local market. She travels to the country every week to purchase her goods and then she brings them back to Ayacucho. Sometimes the vendors come to Ayacucho, so she is able to stay in the area.

Filomena will invest her loan of 1,600 soles in her business by purchasing potatoes, wheat, and soy. The loan will also help her pay the costs of traveling to purchase these goods. Her goal is to continue saving for her old age; she dreams that she will be able to help her children find their destinies and wants to make sure she leaves behind her business to ensure her children are financially secure.

loans.use: To purchase potatoes, wheat, and soy, and to pay for travel to purchase these goods.

loans.name: Lucinda

texts.en:
Lucinda G. D. L. is a member of community bank Obreras, which means "worker" in Spanish. She is married with four children and lives in Ayacucho. To support her family, Lucinda works as a mid-wife, as well as at an artisan workshop. With the help of her niece and son, she also runs a small kiosk with computers that offer internet services.

With her loan of 1800 soles (~$600 USD), she will invest in her various businesses by purchasing materials for the artisan shop, such as yarn, as well as an oven and more computers for her kiosk. With her savings, she hopes to reach her goal of providing for herself and her husband as they grow older.

loans.use: To purchase yarn for her artisan shop, as well as an oven  for her home and more computers for her internet kiosk business.

loans.name: Tumaini

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 27-year-old Tumain M.from Mbeya. She is married with two children aged 2 and 5. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting two dependents who are orphans. Tumain has been running a grocery store since 2005. Her business is selling commodities such as rice, cooking oil, soda, etc. She works at the business for 10 hours per day, 7 days per week and is assisted by her husband. Tumaini currently earns about $30USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of $175USD in order to buy additional stocks of rice, cooking oil, and soda. In the future, she plans to expand the business. Tumaini thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Lending. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a lending microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microlending is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: Tumaini would like to buy additional stocks of rice, cooking oil, and soda for her grocery store.

loans.name: Fatou Binetou

texts.fr: FATOU BINETOU D. EST UNE COMMERCIALISE DES TISSUS BAZINS PAGNES TISSUS Q'ELLE ACHETE AU MALI, BURKINA FASSO, POUR LES REVENDRE AUPRES DE SES CLIENTS DE LA PLACE. ELLE A UNE EXPERIENCE DE 6 ANS. ELLE HABITE LE QUARTIER SOM DE THIES.
texts.en:
Fatou Binetou D. markets 'bazin' fabrics and 'pagnes' (colorful West African cloth) that she buys in Mali and in Burkina Faso in order to resell them to local customers. She has six years of experience. She lives in the SOM district of THIES.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To sell pagnes and bath soap

loans.name: Diarra

texts.fr: Diarra F. est femme mariée vendeuse de poissons depuis plus trois ans. C'est une activité qui lui permet d'entretenir sa famille grâce à ses recettes de 15000 fcfa en moyenne par jour. Elle sollicite ce prêt pour renforcer ses activités et augmenter sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Diarra F. is a married women and has been a retailer of fish for over three years. This is a business that enables her to support her family, thanks to her receipts of 15,000 francs CFA per day on average. She is requesting this loan to bolster her business and to increase her customer base.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Commerce in fish

loans.name: Maguatte Signane

texts.fr: MAGUATTE SIGNANE S. EST COMMERCANTE AU MARCHE CENTRAL DE THIES DEPUIS 15 ANS. ELLE VEBD DES HABITS, OBJETS D'ARTS PAGNES TISSES ETC.......ELLE HABITE AU QUARTIER CITE LAMY A THIES.
texts.en:
MAGUATTE SIGNANE S. has been a merchant at the central market of THIES for fifteen years. She sells outfits, objects of art, woven pagnes (colorful West African cloth), etc.... She lives in the CITE LAME district of THIES.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To sell clothing and art objects

loans.name: Vumilia

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 26-year-old Vumilia L. from Mbeya. She is married with two children, aged 3 and 5. Vumilia has been running a shoe business since 2003. Her business is to buy shoes in whole sale and resell them in retail. She works at the business for 12 hours per day, 6 days per week and is assisted by one employee and her husband. She currently earns about $300 from her business. She is requesting a loan of $400USD in order to purchase additional stock of shoes. In the future, she plans to open another business. Vumilia thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Lending. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a lending microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microlending is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: Vumilia would like to purchase additional stock of shoes.

loans.name: Sokhna Diarra

texts.fr: Sokhna Diarra S. habite à Ouakam, elle est célibataire et exerce le commerce voilà plus de deux ans. Elle peut gagner en moyenne 5000 cfa par jour. Elle Sollicite ce prêt pour renforcer ses activités pour mieux satisfaire sa clientèle
texts.en:
Sokhna Diarra S. lives in Ouakam. She is single and has been in the sales business for more than 2 years. She earns on average 5000 cfa a day. She is requesting this loan to bolster her business so as to better satisfy the needs of her clientele.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: selling clothing

loans.name: María Antonieta

texts.es:
Maria es socia del Banco Comunal Ccori Ayllu que significa Familia de Oro en quechua. Maria es casada, tiene 33 años y 3 hijos, Maria tiene una tienda en su casa ubicada en el distrito de Carmen Alto, en donde vende abarrotes, verduras, frutas, actividad que realiza con la ayuda de sus hijos. Además los días jueves viaja a la feria de Putaja en donde compra animales menores, que luego beneficia en su casa y vende de casa en casa y en algunas oportunidades en los mercados, También los días domingos vende comida en la feria de ganado que se realiza cerca de su casa.

Maria necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de azúcar, arroz, fideo, aceite. Los sueños de Maria son mejorar sus negocios y que sus hijos estudien.
texts.en:
María is a member of the "Ccori Ayllu" Communal Bank which means "Family of Gold" in quechua. She is married, 33 years old and has three children. María has a store in her home located in the Carmen Alto district where she sells groceries, vegetables and fruit - work she does with the help of her children. In addition to that, on Thursdays she travels to the market in Putaja where she purchases young animals and later sells them at home, door to door and sometimes in the markets. Also, on Sundays she sells food in the cattle market near her home.

María needs a loan for 1,000 soles, money that will be invested in the purchase of sugar, rice, noodles and cooking oil. Her dreams are to improve her business and that her children study.

Translated from Spanish by Hugh Yarbrough, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase sugar, rice, noodles and cooking oil

loans.name: Jackelin

texts.es:
Jackelin es socia del Banco Comunal Ccori Ayllu que significa Familia de Oro en quechua. Jackelin es soltera y tiene 20 años, Jackelin estudia Construcción Civil en un instituto publico y vive con sus padres. Jackelin en su tiempo libre por las tardes vende cosméticos por catálogos de dos líneas diferentes, sus productos los ofrece a amigos, familiares y sus ventas en mayor parte son al crédito y cobra diariamente.

Jackelin necesita un préstamo de 2000 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra de cosméticos, colonias, desodorantes. Los sueños de Jackelin son mejorar su negocio, terminar su carrera y ser una profesional de éxito.
texts.en:
Jackelin is a member of the "Ccori Ayllu" Communal Bank which means "Family of Gold" in Quechua. She is single and 20 years old. Jackelin studies civil construction at a public school and lives with her parents. In her free time in the afternoon she sells two different lines of cosmetics from catalogs. She offers her products to friends and family. The majority of her sales are on credit and she collects daily.

Jackelin needs a loan for 2,000 soles, money that will be invested in the purchase of cosmetics, perfumes and deodorants. Her dreams are to improve her business, complete her education and to be a successful professional.

Translated from Spanish by Hugh Yarbrough, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase cosmetics, perfumes and deodorants

loans.name: Maritza Del Socorro

texts.es: La Profesora Suarez de 49 años de edad es originaria de Cuapa, Chontales, trabaja para la Escuela Politecnica 17 de Julio en Juigalpa, con 21 años de servicio; soltera, tiene 1 hijo graduado de Ing. Agrónomo, desempleado, para ayudarle a su madre y asumir sus gastos se está dedicando a la siembra de frijoles, sandia y repasto de un pequeño hato.   La profesora está solicitando su crédito el que utilizará para mejoramiento de su vivienda que está ubicada en Cuapa donde habita su hijo, comprará persianas de vidrio y aluminio para evitar que se le filtre el agua, ya que sólo tiene los protectores de hierro, todos los créditos anteriores los ha invertido en su vivienda.
texts.en:
Professor Suarez, 49 years old, is originally from Cuapa, Chontales, works for the July 17th Polytechnic School in Juigalpa, with 21 years of service. She is single, and has one son who graduated in Agricultural Engineering, who is unemployed, to help his mother to increase her earnings he is dedicating himself to the sale of beans, watermelon and repasto from a small stand. The professor is looking for a loan which she will use to improve her home which is located in Cuapa where her son lives, she will buy glass and aluminum blinds to avoid getting water, because now she only has iron bars. All of her previous loans she has invested in her home.

Translated from Spanish by Zach Frey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy glass and aluminum blinds

loans.name: Eugenia

texts.es:
Eugenia es socia del Banco Comunal Ccori Ayllu que significa Familia de Oro en quechua. Eugenia es casada, tiene 44 años y 5 hijos, Eugenia junto a su esposo elaboran panes, galletas en el horno de su nuera con quien comparten los gastos de luz, Eugenia inicia sus labores los días miércoles durante el día elabora los panes y luego los días jueves los embolsa, sus ventas los realiza en la ciudad de Vilcashuaman a donde viaja todos los días viernes y regresa los días domingos, mientras que su esposo viaja a otras ferias llevando los mismos productos.

Eugenia necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de harina, manteca, azúcar. Los sueños de Eugenia es ampliar su negocio y que sus hijos sean profesionales
texts.en:
Eugenia is a member of the Ccori Ayllu—which means Family of Gold in Quechua—Microfinance Institute. Eugenia is a 44-year-old married mother of 5 children. She and her husband bake bread and cookies in their daughter-in-law’s oven, sharing the electricity bills with her. Eugenia starts her work on Wednesdays, making bread the whole day, then putting it in bags on Thursdays. She sells her baked goods in the city of Vilcashuaman, where she travels on Fridays, then returns on Sundays. Her husband, meanwhile, travels to other markets to sell their goods.

Eugenia needs a loan of 1,000 PEN, which she will invest in purchasing flour, butter, and sugar. She dreams of expanding her business and seeing her children become professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase flour, butter and sugar

loans.name: Alejandrina  Perez

texts.es:
Alejandrina es socia del Banco Comunal Ccori Ayllu que significa Familia D. Oro en quechua. Alejandrina es casada, tiene 56 años y 6 años, Alejandrina junto a su esposo se dedican a la fabricación D. yeso en un local alquilado, las piedras los adquiere en el distrito D. socos que se ubica a 2 horas D. la ciudad D. Ayacucho el cual es transportado con un carro alquilado, luego quema las rocas durante 8 horas para seguidamente moler D. manera artesanal y luego embolsar el yeso.

Alejandrina necesita un préstamo D. 2000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra D. piedras. Los sueños D. Alejandrina son hacer mas granD. su negocio, vender a otros distritos y que su hijo menor termine sus estudios.
texts.en:
Alejandrina is a member of the Ccori Ayllu—which means Family of Gold in Quechua—Microfinance Institute. Alejandrina is a 56-year-old married mother of 6 children. She and her husband manufacture plaster in a rented business space. They obtain the rocks from the Socos district, which is located 2 hours away from the city of Ayacucho. They transport the rocks on a rented truck, and then burn them for 8 hours so that they can grind them in an artisanal manner and put the plaster into bags.

Alejandrina needs a loan of 2,000.00 PEN, which will be invested in purchasing rocks. Alejandrina dreams of expanding her business, selling her products in other districts, and seeing her youngest son complete his studies.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase rocks

loans.name: Juana Pilar

texts.es:
Juana es socia del Banco Comunal Ccori Ayllu que significa Familia de Oro en quechua. Juana es casada, tiene 41 años y 5 hijos, Juana tiene un taller de confección de prendas de vestir ubicado en su casa, Juana confecciona ropa típica de la región como centros, actividad que realiza con la ayuda de su esposo e hijos, sus ventas lo realiza en el mercado de la ciudad de Ayacucho. Juana tiene proyectado iniciar un nuevo negocio de venta de abarrotes en su casa.

Juana necesita un préstamo de 1200 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de telas, hilos. Juana sueña con tener una tienda en el centro de la ciudad donde venda sus productos y que sus hijos sean profesionales.
texts.en:
Juana is a partner in the Ccori Ayllu Communal Bank, a name that means “Family of Gold” in Quechua. Juana is 41 years old and married, with five children. She owns a sewing shop, which she manages with the help of her husband and children. The shop is located in her home, and she sews traditional clothing and sells it in the markets of Ayacucho. Juana hopes to launch a new grocery store business, also in her home. Juana needs a loan of 1200 soles, which she’ll invest in fabric and thread. She dreams of having a store in the center of the city, where she can sell her products. Juana would also like her children to become professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Sarah Bishop, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Juana needs a loan of 1200 soles, which will be invested in fabric and thread.

loans.name: Juana Soledad

texts.es:
Juana es socia del Banco Comunal Ccori Ayllu que significa Familia de Oro en quechua. Juana es casada, tiene 50 años y 7 hijos, Juana se dedica confección de ropa típica, tiene un taller de confección de prendas de vestir ubicado en su casa, actividad que realiza con la ayuda de su esposo e hijos, sus ventas lo realiza en el mercado de la ciudad de Ayacucho y también en su misma casa.

Juana necesita un préstamo de 1800 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de telas, hilos. Los sueños de Juana son que todos sus hijos terminen sus estudios y sean profesionales, tener otro negocio y su familia sea feliz.
texts.en:
Juana is a partner in the Ccori Ayllu Communal Bank, whose name means “Family of Gold” in Quetchua. Juana is 50 years old and married, with 7 children. She sews traditional clothing in her workshop, located in her home. She manages her business with help from her husband and children, and sells her products in the Ayacucho markets and in her home. Juana needs a loan of 1800 soles, which she’ll invest in fabrics and thread. Juana dreams of her children finishing their studies and becoming professionals, of having another business and of her family being happy.

Translated from Spanish by Sarah Bishop, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Juana needs a loan of 1800 soles, which she'll use to invest in fabric and thread.

loans.name: Mariama

texts.fr: Mariama D. est une vendeuse de poissons qui a trente ans d'expérience. Elle est mariée et grâce à ses revenues, elle s'occupe bien de sa fmille et de lui même. Elle peut gagner dés fois jusqu'à 15000 fcfa par jour. Elle sollicite ce prêt pour renfoacer ses activités et augmenter ses recettes.
texts.en:
Mariama D. is a fish-seller with 30 years' experience. She is married and thanks to her earnings she supports herself and her family. She is able sometimes to earn up to 15,000 F CFA per day. She is requesting this loan to bolster her business and increase her income.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: fish-selling

loans.name: Marelina

texts.es:
Marelina Es socia del Banco Comunal Ccori Ayllu que significa Familia de Oro en quechua. Marelina es conviviente, tiene 23 años y 1 hija, Marelina vende quesos que compra al por mayor en los mercados y terminales terrestres de la ciudad de Ayacucho, para luego transportarlo a la ciudad de Lima actividad que realiza 1 vez por mes. Además Marelina vende cosméticos por catálogos que ofrece a amigos y familiares. Merelina junto a su esposo tiene un carro con el cual su esposo realiza transporte.

Marelina necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles dinero que será invertido en el arreglo de su carro. Marelina sueña con comprar otro carro, su hija sea profesional y que su familia sea feliz.
texts.en:
Marelina is a partner in the Ccori Ayllu Communal Bank, which means "Family of Gold" in Quechua. Marelina is 23 years old and lives with her husband and daughter. She buys cheese wholesale in Ayacucho, then once each month she transports it to Lima for individual sale. She also sells makeup to friends and family from catalogs. Merelina and her husband have a car, which he uses to offer transportation services. Marelina needs a loan of 1000 soles, which she'll invest in repairs for her car. Marelina dreams of buying a second car, of her daughter becoming a professional, and of her family being happy.

Translated from Spanish by Sarah Bishop, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Mareline needs a loan of 1000 soles, which she'll invest in maintenance for her car.

loans.name: Esther

texts.es:
Esther Es socia del Banco Comunal Agua Viva. Esther es conviviente, tiene 34 años y 4 hijos, Esther viaja a diferentes ferias de la región en donde compra quesos, cereales para luego transportarlo a la ciudad de Ayacucho y comercializarlo en los mercados. Además Esther viaja a la ciudad de Andahuaylas en donde compra carbón que luego lo vende en la ciudad de Ayacucho, repartiendo a las pollerias y restaurantes.

Esther necesita un préstamo de 2100 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de cereales. Esther sueña con mejorar su negocio y brindar una buena educación a sus hijos.
texts.en:
Esther is a member of the Agua Viva Microfinance Institute. Esther is a 34-year-old woman with a live-in partner and 4 children. She travels to different markets in the region to buy cheese and grains, which she then transports the city of Ayacucho to sell in the markets. Esther also travels to the city of Andahuaylas, where she buys charcoal in order to sell it in Ayacucho, distributing it to grilled chicken restaurants and other types of restaurants.

Esther needs a loan of 2,100.00 PEN, which she will invest in purchasing grains. Esther dreams of improving her business and of giving her children a good education.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase grains

loans.name: Lidia Beatrís

texts.es: La Sra. Ramirez ejerce su negocio en su casa de habitación ubicada de la Esso 8 cuadras al Oeste en la zona 3 del municipio de juigalpa, durante ocho años se ha dedicado al acopio de pequeña cantidad de leche y procesarla en cuajadas, queso, para después venderla y por la tarde prepara enchiladas, tajadas con quezo y carnes; las que vende a estudiantes y personas que transitan por el lugar, es casada con el Sr. Juan Carlos Miranda de 49 años de edad, sus dos hijas estudian la secundaria, producto de su esfuerzo y sacrificio diario, ya que muy temprano se levanta al acopio de la leche y preparan a sus niñas para el colegio, luego procesa leche. Su sueño es algun día terminar de acondicionar un local para su comederia ya que es una actividad que desarrolla y su clientela esta en crecimiento y desea dedicarle todo su tiempo al negocio
texts.en:
Mrs. Ramirez has her business in her house located 8 blocks west of the Esso in Zone 3 of the municipality of Juigalpa. For eight years she has dedicated herself to getting small quantities of milk and processing it into cheese, to later sell, and during the afternoon she prepares enchiladas with cheese and meat, which she sells to the students and people who pass by her place. She is married to Mr. Juan Carlos Miranda, 49, and their two daughters are in high school as a product of their strength and daily sacrifice, since she gets up very early every day to get the milk and to prepare her daughters for school, and later makes the milk. Her dream is to one day stop looking for a spot for her restaurant, now that it is a successful activity, and her clientele is growing and she wants to dedicate all of her time to the business.

Translated from Spanish by Zach Frey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Compra de leche y acondiciomaniemto de local

loans.name: Rosa

texts.es:
Primer préstamo: http://www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&action=about&id=40575&_tpos=1&_tpg=1

Rosa es socia del Banco Comunal Agua Viva. Rosa es conviviente, tiene 29 años y 1 hijo de 13 años, Rosa se dedica a la elaboración de chocolates ayacuchanos, que elabora sola y de manera domestica, actividad que aprendió mientras trabajaba, sus insumos los adquiere al por mayor, el cacao lo compra en la selva ayacuchana, en los últimos meses sus ventas se incrementaron porque vende a tiendas mayoristas, su producción se ha incrementado.

Rosa necesita un préstamo de 1050 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de azúcar. Rosa sueña con que su hija progrese, sea profesional, ampliar su negocio y tener una empresa.
texts.en:
First Loan: http://www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&action=about&id=40575&_tpos=1&_tpg=1 Rosa is a partner in the "Agua Viva" Communal Bank. Rosa is 29 years old and lives with her husband and 13 year old daughter. She makes chocolates typical of the city of Ayacucho. She makes it by herself in her home, and she learned the trade while she was working. Rosa acquires her supplies wholesale. She buys cacao in the Ayacuchan jungle. In recent months her sales have gone up because she began selling at wholesale stores, and her production has increased as a result. Rosa needs a loan of 1050 soles, which she'll invest in sugar. Rosa dreams of her child progressing in school, becoming a professional, expanding her business and having a store of her own.

Translated from Spanish by Sarah Bishop, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Rosa needs a loan of 1050 soles which she'll invest in sugar

loans.name: Maria Elena

texts.es:
Marielena es socia del Banco Comunal Agua Viva. Marielena es conviviente, tiene 32 años y 2 hijos, Marielena junto a su esposo tienen una botica ubicado en un local alquilado que se encuentra en una calle cercana al mercado central de la ciudad de Ayacucho, Además Marielena en los últimos meses implemento cabinas de internet en otro local cercano que también es alquilado.

Marielena necesita un préstamo de 1200 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de medicamentos. Marielena sueña con tener una casa propia, ampliar su negocio con sucursales, buena educación a sus hijos y casarse.
texts.en:
Marielena is a partner in the "Agua Viva" Communal Bank. Marielena is 32 years old and lives with her partner and two children. Marielena and her partner have a pharmacy in a rented store near the central market in Ayacucho. Marielena has been installing internet connections in another store nearby. Marielena needs a loan of 1200 soles, which she will invest in medicines. She dreams of having her own home, expanding her business with more branches, and providing her children with a better education, and getting married.

Translated from Spanish by Sarah Bishop, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Marielena needs a loan of 1200 soles, which she'll use to buy medicines.

loans.name: Gina Del Carmen

texts.es: La profesora Gina de 35 años de edad trabaja en un instituto como encargada de los servicios de capacitación desde hace 10 años, está casada con Herry Antonio Chacón, tienen 1 hijo de 15 años estudiando el 4to. Año de secundaria. La profesora M. está solicitando su crédito Nº 3 el que utilizará para mejorar su vivienda. Los créditos anteriores los utilizó para trámites de cursos de graduación y tramitación de títulos, ha sido una excelente clienta con buen récord crediticio, responsable con el pago de sus cuotas y sus créditos en general. Es una persona sacrificada ya que su horario de trabajo es de 7:30 am a 8:00 pm de lunes a sábado y el domingo de 7:30 am a 2:30 pm; únicamente pasa con su hijo por las noches y el domingo la tarde, esto lo hace con el afán de asegurar un mejor ingreso y hacer frente a la situación económica, recibe apoyo de su esposo quien trabaja en construcción. Su casa y su hijo son cuidados por su mamá que está cerca de ella.
texts.en:
