Elle fait des friandises (beignets) et de la petite restauration à savoir (préparation du haricot, de la spagueti etc).  Très  connue et appréciée grâce à la qualité de ses plats alimentaires, elle a une clientèle qui grossit de jour en jour.
Dans le souci de maintenir cette clientèle de plus en plus importante, elle décida de rejoindre le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso avec lequel elle est en relation depuis 3 ans. Elle est à son deuxième prêt individuel après 4 prêts de groupe (prêt solidaire) tous remboursés sans difficultés
Elle s’approvisionne en matières premières au grand marché de Koutiala auprès des grossistes et fait sa cuisine devant sa porte sise au quartier Hamdallaye. Les beignets, haricots et spagueti ainsi préparés sont vendus devant la concession conjugale. La clientèle est constituée de toutes les catégories sociales de la cité. Elle vend chaque jour et cela durant toute l’année généralement au comptant et quelques fois à crédit.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice de 60.000FCFA par mois qu’elle  compte utiliser pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt et participer aux dépenses quotidiennes de la famille. Dans l’avenir , son ambition  c’est d’ouvrir un restaurant.
texts.en:
Mrs. Salimata Konaté is 32 years old and lives with her five children and her husband in a monogamous family in the Hamdallaye village (Prefecture of Koutiala, third administrative region in the Republic of Mali). So as to get a footing in economic life, she started several businesses, without success. In the end, she settled for the food-serving business eight years ago. She makes and serves snacks (beignets) and simple dishes (beans, spaghetti, etc). Well known and much appreciated thanks to the quality of her cooking, she has a clientele that is expanding every day. Anxious to maintain her ever-increasing clientele, she decided to join the loan program of Soro Yiriwaso three years ago. She's now seeking her second personal loan after four group loans (solidarity loans) that were repaid without problems. She purchases raw materials from wholesale sellers in the grand market in Koutiala and does her cooking in front of her door in the Hamdallaye neighborhood. Beignets, beans and spaghetti are thus prepared and sold in front of the family house. Her clientele comes from all social categories in the city. Her business is open daily and all year long. She usually sells for cash and sometimes on credit. She foresees that she will make a monthly profit of XOF 60'000 (ca US$ 120), to be used to repay the loan and help with the daily family expenses. In the future, her ambition is to open a restaurant.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sacks of bean, boxes of spaghetti and condiments

loans.name: Mok

texts.en: Mok Y. is married and lives with four of her children in Kampong Cham, Cambodia. She has a business selling fruits and rubber to earn a living and is able to make around US$8 per day, while her husband works to propagate the rubber trees. Mok is asking a loan of US$750 to purchase bean seeds and the rest of the money will be used to grow more rubber trees.

loans.use: Mok would like to purchase bean seeds and grow rubber trees.

loans.name: Chan

texts.en:
Mrs. Chan S. is a villager in Chong Ankor Village in Takeo Province. She owns a plot of land to till to earn her living. In this plantation, she now faces an obstacle because her field is infertile so she is requesting a loan to purchase fertilizer to improve her field to make her crops more productive. Her husband, Mr. Loeng Sam Ang, is a fisherman who can catch a few fish to sell for an income to supplement the earnings for the household.

Mrs. Chan S. is 40 years old and the mother of six children, four of whom are attending the local school while the remaining two are too young to work or study because they are two and four years old. Her husband is also in the photo.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer to make her crops more productive

loans.name: Noun

texts.en: Noun S. was born in 1972 and is married with two children. She and her husband have a butchery stand at home that sells pork. In the early morning her husband has to buy pork from a butcher in his town and then the couple starts reselling it at their stand. With their business activity, they can collectively make $5/day of profit. Noun and her husband need more money to expand the quantity of their pork because right now the price of pork is slightly up and the demand is increasing.

loans.use: Noun would like to buy more pork for their business.

loans.name: Chan

texts.en:
Chan K., 28, is married and lives about 124 miles from the capital of Phnom Penh city, Cambodia. Living in the Kampong Cham, she and her husband typically make US$3 each day. She says every day she and her husband walk their bicycle to purchase recycling items from house to house in the village and sell them to the recycling plant. This couple together has one child.

Chan K. would like to take out a loan of US$700 to purchase recyling items in a large amount. For her future plans, she wants her child to complete at least high school and, if he needs to continue, she will strongly support him even though she knows that she will spend a lot, as she wants him to get a better job in the future. (Husband is pictured)

loans.use: To purchase recycling items in a large amount.

loans.name: Dilbar

texts.en: Dilbar has a big family with five children. So to feed her family, she and two of her children sell grocery products at the market, which they have been doing for 8 years. By doing this, they support their family. Now she wants to borrow money to buy more goods to sell and with more profit, she wants to expand her business and provide a better living for her children.

loans.use: Dilbar would like to purchase more grocery goods to resell to improve her business.

loans.name: Chan

texts.en:
Mrs. Chan P. is a farmer in Chong Ankor Village in Takeo Province. In this plantation, her field now is not fertile which has a bad effect on her crop. In order to solve this problem, she is requesting a loan to purchase fertilizer to improve her field. Her husband, Mr. Nuon Say, is a motorbike taxi driver who can make US$ 3 a day which is a meager income to support his family.

Mrs. Chan P. is 28 years old and the mother of three children, two of whom are enrolled in the local school while the youngest one is too young to work or study because that child is two years old. Her husband is also in the photo.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer to support her field

loans.name: Fatoumata Sidi

texts.fr:
Madame Fatoumata Sidi M. est âgée de 38 ans et vit avec son mari, ses 5 enfants et autres parents dans la famille paternelle (traditionnelle élargie) dans le quartier Hamdallaye A de la ville de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Elle abandonna l’école en classe de 7èmeannée de l’enseignement fondamental pour s’adonner aux activités génératrices de revenus afin de subvenir à ses besoins. Après plusieurs années d’apprentissage auprès de sa belle mère, elle s’installe dans le secteur de la nourriture en vendant des poissons séchés depuis 6 ans. Elle jouit d’une grande expérience et d’une notoriété sans égale à Ségou d’où son sobriquet de Jege jalan Faty (Faty la vendeuse de poisson séché). Après l’achat d’une certaine quantité de poissons frais , elle procède au lavage et au séchage au soleil à l’abri de la poussière et des mouches. Ensuite les poissons sont découpés en morceaux avant de les revendre.
 Elle est à son premier prêt individuel. Avec Soro Yiriwaso et compte l’utiliser pour acheter, 5 paniers de poissons frais sur place à Ségou auprès de grossistes venant de Mopti.
Madame Fatoumata Sidi M. vend au marché Château à une clientèle composée essentiellement de femmes. Ses ventes se réalisent toujours au comptant.
Elle espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 40 000FCFA,  lequel lui permettra de payer les trousseaux de mariage de sa fille et d’augmenter le volume de son activité.
Son ambition est de construire une maison d’habitation et acheter une certaine quantité d’or .
texts.en:
Ms. Fatoumata Sidi M. is 38 years old and lives with her husband, her five children, and parents in a paternal family (traditional and extended) in the Hamdallaye A district of the city of Ségou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). She abandoned school in the seventh grade to dedicate herself to earning an income in order to support herself. After several years apprenticing with her mother-in-law, she got settled six years ago in the food sector selling dried fish. She enjoys much experience and unparalleled fame in Ségou, where she earned the nickname “Jege jalan Faty” (Faty the Dried Fish Seller). After buying a certain quantity of fresh fish, she washes them and then dries them in the sun. She protects them from dust and flies. Next, the fish are cut into pieces before being sold. She is on her first individual loan with Soro Yiriwaso and intends to use the loan to buy 5 baskets of fresh fish locally in Ségou from wholesalers coming from Mopti. Ms. Fatoumata Sidi M. makes her sales at the Château marketplace to customers composed essentially of women. Sales are always made in cash. She hopes to realize a monthly profit of 40,000 francs CFA, which will enable her to pay for a marital hope chest for her daughter and to increase the volume of her business. Her ambition is to construct a house in which to live and to buy a certain quantity of gold.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fresh fish

loans.name: Yorn

texts.en: Yorn S. is a 49-year-old farmer growing rice in Dorn Sok Village. She earns around US$2 per day. She is married to Mr. Ngin Khoun, 43, who is a fisherman. Yorn has five children, one of whom is married and does not live at home. The other four live at home, and two of them help with fishing, and the other two are in school. To improve the family's living condition, Yorn needs a loan of US$1100 to purchase wood for building a suitable house for her family.

loans.use: Yorn would like to purchase wood for building a house.

loans.name: Pich

texts.en: Mrs. Pich N. is a villager in Angk Prasath Village in Takeo Province. She and her husband, Mr. Mak Chan, are poultry breeders who raise ducks. Since this business is going well, they want to expand it, so Mrs. Pich N. decided to ask for a loan to buy two-hundred more ducks for breeding. Mrs. Pich N. is 28 years old and the mother of two children, one of whom is attending the local school while the other is too young to work or study because that child is at the age of four years old. Her husband is present on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To buy two-hundred more ducks for breeding.

loans.name: Lamine

texts.fr:
Monsieur Lamine Sangaré est un jeune de 27 ans qui vit avec sa femme et ses 2 enfants dans une famille traditionnelle avec d’autres ménages dans le quartier Sido Sonincoura de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Ayant très tôt abandonné l’école coranique il s’adonna au métier de jardinier, grâce à laquelle activité il génère son premier fonds de commerce. Monsieur Sangaré fait la vente des huiles alimentaires depuis maintenant 6 ans. Jouissant d’une très grande popularité auprès des femmes fréquentant le marché Château de la ville de Ségou, il vend exclusivement en détail à l’aide d’une pompe manuelle qui lui sert d’instrument de mesure (Chaque tour de la manivelle coûte 100 FCFA la monnaie locale).
Pour satisfaire la demande de sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, il sollicite le concours de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui il est à son premier prêt individuel. 
Il compte utiliser ce prêt pour acheter, 600 litres d’huile alimentaire (soit trois fûts d’huile) auprès des commerçants grossistes sur place au grand marché de la ville de Ségou.
Monsieur Lamine Sangaré vend au comptant ou à crédit au marché château de Ségou sous un hangar à une clientèle composée généralement de ménagères et de restauratrices. En raison de l’augmentation régulière de sa clientèle  monsieur Sangaré pense devenir dans les années à venir une référence dans son domaine à Ségou.
texts.en:
Mr. Lamine Sangaré is a 27-year-old young man who lives with his wife and his two children in a traditional family along with other married couples in the Sido Sonincoura district of Ségou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Having abandoned Koranic school very early on, he dedicated himself to the gardening profession. Thanks to that work, he generated his own capital fund. Mr. Sangaré has been selling cooking oil for six years now. Enjoying tremendous popularity with the women who visit the Château marketplace in the city of Ségou, he sells exclusively at the retail level and uses a hand pump as a measuring device. (Each turn of the crank costs 100 francs CFA, the local currency). To satisfy the demand from his continuously growing customer base, he is requesting the assistance of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with which he is on his first individual loan. He intends to use this loan to buy 600 liters of cooking oil (being three drums worth) from wholesale merchants locally at the grand marketplace of the city of Ségou. At the Château marketplace of Ségou, Mr. Sangaré makes his sales out of a shed to customers generally composed of housewives and restaurateurs, cash or credit accepted. Because of the regular increase of customers, Mr. Sangaré is thinking of becoming a reference in his domain in Ségou in the years to come.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cooking oil

loans.name: Kong

texts.en: Kong N., 49, is married and lives with three of her children in the Kampong Cham, Cambodia. Since 2002, she has been worked selling rice cake and boiled corn to earn a living and is able to make around US$5 per day, while her husband is a horse-cart driver, making US$2 per day to support the family. One of their children is employed and one is a student and one is too young to go to school. Kong N. would like to take out a loan of US$1000 to purchase a horse to resell. (Her husband is pictured.)

loans.use: To purchase horse to resell.

loans.name: Phe

texts.en:
Phe S., 38, works growing rice and various kinds of vegetables on her paddy. From selling her outputs to the people in the village as well as at a market, she can typically generate around $3/day of income. Her husband is striving to earn the family income by charging batteries for the people in his village. The government electricity source has not reached his community so the people in the village use batteries to generate electricity instead. From his business he can earn around $5/day of income for his household.

Phe S. and her husband are really happy to see their businesses growing, but they still need more capital to enable them to purchase a bigger machine that can charge a lot more batteries at a time. A new machine can save them a lot of time.

loans.use: To buy a machine that can charge more batteries.

loans.name: Jema

texts.en:
Jema, age 49, has owned a small shop, or kiosk, in Zanzibar for 10 years. She sells a variety of small household items and snacks.

She is currently able to earn a profit of approximately $40 each month. She is hopeful that as a result of her first loan from BRAC Tanzania, she will be able to increase her profit.

For 10 years she has stocked her shop with only her minimal monthly profits, so access to this larger lump sum will help her to boost the inventory in her shop beyond what she has otherwise been capable of.

loans.use: To buy more inventory for her small shop.

loans.name: Parvina

texts.en:
Parvina sells groceries in the market. She has a small store in the market where she sells the goods. She has had this business for many years.

Parvina also has a business selling cell phones. Her sister works with her to help sell the phones.

Parvina wants to borrow money so she can buy more goods to sell. With the greater profits, she wants to provide a better living for her family.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery goods and cell phones to sell

loans.name: Chab

texts.en:
Chab S., 41, is married and lives with three of her children and her husband in the Kampong Cham, Cambodia. Since 2000, she has been working selling rice cakes and boiled duck eggs from her home. In the morning, she sells rice cakes and in the evening, she sells duck eggs, and on average she makes around US$3 per day.

Her husband works in a recycling business and with a motor-taxi. He said that earlier, he just ran a motor-taxi, but since the price of gas keeps increasing, he has started to increase his other business in purchasing recycling items to add to the family's income.

Chab S. would like to take out a loan of US$500 to purchase a trailer to transport recycling products, and the rest will be used to increase the amount of stuff they have to sell.

loans.use: To purchase a trailer.

loans.name: Mariétou

texts.fr: Mariétou T. est une vendeuse à Ouakam qui a huit ans d'expérience. Elle est mariée et grâce et son commerce, elle entretien sa famille. Elle peut souvent gagner jusqu'à 10000 fcfa par jour. Elle sollicite un crédit pour renforcer ses activités en vue d'augmenter ses revenues et améliorer ainsi sa situation.
texts.en:
Mariétou T. is a salesperson in Ouakam who has 8 years of experience. She is married and thanks to her business, she suports her family. She can often earn up to 10,000 F CFA per day. She is requesting this loan to bolster her business so that she can improve her earnings and thus her living conditions.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: selling cloth and incense

loans.name: Jamilya

texts.en: Jamilya G. sells phone cards at the market. She buys cards for about 300 somoni each and sells ten to fifteen of them every day. She also rented a Xerox copier for copying documents for money. She doesn't have much profit from this business right now, but she hopes that if she borrows money she can buy more cards to sell. Thus she will have more profit and can provide a better living for her family.

loans.use: Purchasing more phone cards for greater sales.

loans.name: Nhim

texts.en: Nhim S. Y., 34, is married and lives with two young children in the Kampong Cham, Cambodia. Since 1990, she has been growing yams to earn a living and is able to make around US$5 each day, while her husband is a taxi driver, earning about US$5 as well. Mrs. Nhim S. Y. would like to take out a loan of US$500 to rent a farm to raise yams for sale.

loans.use: To rent a farm to raise yams.

loans.name: Un

texts.en:
Un C. was born in 1970 and is the mother of three children aged 10, 7 and 5 years old. She and her husband work breeding pigs to generate income. After participating in a training about agricultural understanding and how to breed pigs and poultry properly, conducted by a CEDAC, a local organization, this couple has a lot of idea and wanted to try to improve their living conditions.

Initially, they started buying only a few pigs to breed because they had not enough capital. Pig breeding is doing well for them and they are willing to purchase a few more pigs to raise. After hearing from their neighbor about CREDIT MFI from which they could take a loan to use for their livestock expansion, this couple has asked for a $1000 loan to help them purchase more pigs and a motor-bike to use for their business transportation.

loans.use: To buy more pigs to breed and a motor-bike to use for their business transportation.

loans.name: Sihaba

texts.en:
Sihaba is a 41 year old widow with one child. She has been selling fish in Zanzibar for two years. She is currently able to earn a profit of approximately $35 each month.

Sihaba is hoping that taking her first loan from BRAC Tanzania will allow her to buy more food to expand her business and increase her profit.

loans.use: To buy more food to sell at her shop.

loans.name: Sina

texts.en: Sina B. is 45 years old and is married to Mr. Ros Samnang, 49, who farms and sells wood carvings. Sina has six children, two of whom are married and four of whom still live at home; one is a motorcycle taxi driver. She sells groceries in Porpet Village. Sina has been selling groceries since 2002 and currently earns around $2.50 per day. To grow her business, Sina needs a loan of $350 to purchase more inventory to sell and to purchase a buffalo to use for her husband's business.

loans.use: To purchase grocery inventory to sell and to purchase a buffalo to use for her husband's business

loans.name: Jamshed

texts.en:
Jamshed owns a small store in the market where he sells furniture. He sells sofas, chandeliers and windows.

Now he wants to expand his business by borrowing money. He is asking for $500 to grow his business. He promises to repay the loan in 12 months.

loans.use: To purchase more furniture to sell

loans.name: Va

texts.en:
Va S., 26, is married and lives with three young children in the Kampong Cham, Cambodia. She is a dealer, purchasing rubber, beans and yams and then reselling them to the big dealer in the village to earn a living. She is able to make around US$5 per day, while her husband operates a motor-taxi, earning US$4 per day. One of their children is a student.

Va S. would like to take out a loan of US$1200 to purchase produce in bulk. This way, she can save money and also expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase rubber and beans for resale.

loans.name: Rubina Salamat's Group

texts.en:
Rubina baji is the wife of Mr. S. and lives in a small area named Bund Road in the city of Lahore, Pakistan. She has a two-room brick house and has been living in it for the last six years. She is the mother of three children: two sons and one daughter. All of her children are enrolled in a local school in her neighborhood. Her husband is a driver by profession. He has been driving a rented auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle) for the last ten years. Rubina baji is a housewife and prefers to do household work and take care of her family. She is applying for a loan to buy her own auto-rickshaw.

Rubina baji is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Rani baji wants a loan to buy a sewing machine to sew clothes. Taji baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop. Parveen baji wants a loan to repair an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle).

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle)

loans.name: Sharifa

texts.en: Sharifa J. sells women's shirts at the market. She has done this for many years. Her shirts are very good and cheap and that's why she has many clients. She has always wanted to expand her business, and now she can by borrowing money.

loans.use: Purchasing women's shirts for sale.

loans.name: Shazia Kala Masih's Group

texts.en:
Shazia baji is a daughter of K. M. and lives in a small area named Bund Road in the city of Lahore, Pakistan. She has been living in this area for the last 20 years. She completed her education until 10th standard [grade]. She has one brother. Her brother is a driver by profession and drives a rented auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle) and earns a profit. She is applying for a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw for her brother so that he is able to earn a better profit.

Shazia baji is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Fozia baji wants a loan to buy more clothes to resell. Nargis baji wants a loan to buy a donkey cart for loading. Lubna baji wants a loan to buy more wood to resell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle)

loans.name: Salha

texts.en:
Salha is 26 years old, married, and has a two-and-a-half year old child. She has owned a shop in Zanzibar selling clothing, kanga, and perfumes for two years.

Kanga is a local fabric that can be found in a variety of bright colors and with an array of patterns. A local adage is written in Swahili on each kanga. The fabric is used for clothing, table cloths, baby slings, towels, and many other purposes.

Salha is currently able to earn a profit of approximately $80 each month but she is hoping that her first loan from BRAC Tanzania enables her to expand her business and increase her profit. She will use the loan to buy more clothing, kanga, and perfume for her shop.

loans.use: To buy more clothing, kanga, and perfume for her shop.

loans.name: Faida

texts.en:
Faida began selling food in Zanzibar ten years ago. She is now able to earn a monthly profit of approximately $50. For the first time, Faida has access to capital and she is hoping that with this loan she will be able to increase her inventory and grow her profit.

Faida is married and has a 5-year-old child.

loans.use: To buy more inventory for her shop

loans.name: Srey

texts.en: Srey C. is 32 years old and she lives in Roleapea, Kampong Chhnang Province.  She is married with three children, all of whom live at home and are in school. Her husband, Mr. Uch Chroch, is a construction worker, earning about $1.67 per day. Srey sells groceries in her area, earning approximately $10 per day. To expand her business, Srey needs a loan of $1,200 to purchase grocery inventory to sell, as well as purchasing rice to stock for resale when prices are high.  Srey and her husband are in the picture.

loans.use: To purchase grocery inventory and rice to sell.

loans.name: Subira

texts.en:
Subira is married and has three children who are three, ten, and eleven years old. She has had a small shop selling clothing and perfumes in Zanzibar for four years. She is currently able to earn approximately $10 each month.

Subira is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she may use the capital to expand her business and increase her profit. She will use this loan to buy more clothing and perfumes for her shop.

loans.use: To buy more clothing and perfumes for her shop.

loans.name: Dilorom

texts.en: Dilorom K. rents a small atelier where she sews dresses for clients. She also has four students whom she teaches how to sew traditional dresses. She has been sewing for almost 16 years now. She wants to borrow money for buying materials and instruments for sewing so that she can offer better service to her clients.

loans.use: Purchasing materials for sewing dresses for sale.

loans.name: Maisara

texts.en: Maisara makes national bread and sells it at the market. She doesn't have much money for her business because flour and other ingredients are getting so expensive. She also has five children in her family. Her husband went to the Russian Federation searching a better paying job so they could feed their family. Maisara wants to borrow money to expand her business so she can provide a better living for her family.

loans.use: Buy flour and other ingredients for making national bread.

loans.name: Sokunthea

texts.en: Mrs. Sokunthea D. is 42 years old.  She is widowed, with two children who live at home and attend school; one drives a motorcycle taxi in his spare time. She makes clay stoves to sell in her village. She has been making them since 1990 and earns about $5 per day. To increase her productivity, Sokunthea would like to request a loan of 3,000,000 Riel (US$750) to purchase more clay to make stoves to sell. She will also use the loan to purchase groceries to sell. The loan will allow her to increase her family's income.

loans.use: To purchase more clay to make stoves to sell

loans.name: Oeu

texts.en:
Oeu, S., 50, is married with six children and lives in Prey Veng province, Cambodia. She and her husband work buying fish from a river dock to resell at a market for a profit. Each day she can typically make around $5/day of profit. 
This couple has applied a loan from KIVA to purchase more fish to increase their profit.

loans.use: To purchase more fish to increase her profit margin.

loans.name: Gullzaman

texts.en:
This is Gullzaman, son of G., and he is 43 years old. He is married and the father of nine children, and he is uneducated. He lives in Nangarhar province, Jalalabad city. He is a good farmer and has his own land in his village. He grows different kinds of vegetables on his land.

Gullzaman has four sons and five daughters. His eldest son is a painter and is working in the Kabul. His second son is a student of fifth class in the public school and helps his father in his spare time. They live in a large single house in the village.

Gullzaman wishes to buy some seeds and other things for his land, and a motorcar. For that, he needs 50000AF / US$1075 as an individual loan. He contacted the lender AFSG and requested that they give him this much for 18 months. He has his own capital of 50000AF that he wants to include with this loan to buy a motorcar, so he can easily transport his vegetables for sale at the bazaar. He says "thanks" to Kiva - Loans That Change Lives.

loans.use: To buy some seeds and other things for his land, and a motorcar

loans.name: Fadhila

texts.en:
Fadhila has owned a genge in Zanzibar for five years. A genge is a stand that sells fruits and vegetables. It can be as small as a plank of wood with a few dozen tomatoes on a small dirt road or as large as a market stall with a huge variety of fruits and vegetables in a busy city center.

Fadhila is 34 years old, married, and has two children, ages 5 and 10. She is currently able to earn a profit of approximately $120. She is looking forward to taking out her first loan through BRAC Tanzania so that she can expand her inventory and increase her profit.

loans.use: To buy fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Janet Namuli's Group

texts.en:
Janet is the leader of a 5 member group. 

She is 52 years old and married with 8 children. Her children are between the ages of 10 and 25 years. Three of her children go to school. Janet resides in and owns a six-roomed house. They do have electricity and piped water at home. She lives in the house with five others. Janet also takes care of her old mother and two grandchildren. The family can afford three meals each day. 

Janet resides and works in a semi-urban area, which is in the outskirts of Kampala. Janet sells second hand clothes. She goes from door to door, looking for customers. At times, she displays her goods at home for sale. On average, she can sell to 10 people each day. Janet buys the clothing she sells from the Owino Market, one of the busiest markets in Kampala. 

She has been in this business for fifteen years. She works six days a week. Her major challenges are the rainy season and taxes. 

Janet has been with MCDT for seven years. This will be her 14th loan. She aspires to expand her business and increase her profits so can begin selling in the wholesale market.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Safaa

texts.en:
Safaa is 27 years old. She has been selling clothing and perfume in Zanzibar for two years and is able to earn a monthly profit of approximately $60 from her shop.

She is hoping that this first loan from BRAC Tanzania enables her to expand her inventory and increase her profit. She will use the loan to buy more clothes and perfume for her shop.

loans.use: To buy more clothes and perfume for her shop.

loans.name: Sopun's Group

texts.en:
This is a group loan and there are 5 members. Mr. Sopun P. is a lathe operator. He has been working since 1995 and currently earns around $5 per day. He lives with his elderly father who stays home. To expand his business, Sopun needs a loan of $350 to use for his lathe operation. Sopun is the group leader; the other members are:

1- Sambo M. is widowed and sells cooked rice. She needs a loan of $300 to add to her saved money to purchase a second-hand motorcycle to transport her rice to sell. 
2- Saron C. sells groceries and needs a loan of $300 to purchase grocery inventory to sell.
3- Dina P. sells sugarcane juice. She needs a loan of $300 to purchase sugarcane and to build a small store to serve clients.
4- Chhin P. is widowed and sells porridge. She needs a loan of $300 to purchase piglets to breed. 

This group of people lives in Prek Preahsdach Commune, Battambang Province.

loans.use: To use for his lathe operation

loans.name: Mavluda

texts.en: Mavluda is the mother of five children. It's not easy to feed such a big family so her husband went to Russia for a better paying job. To help support her family, Mavluda sells dried fruits at the market. First she started by selling fried turn-overs and some dried fruits. Now she wants to expand her business and help her husband in supporting and feeding their family.

loans.use: Purchasing dried fruits

loans.name: Mingboi

texts.en: Mingboi F. has a very big family -- 8 kids. He loves kids very much (maybe that is why he has so many kids). He is a high school teacher, but his teacher's salary isn't enough to feed such a big family. That's why he started his business of selling rice at the market.  First, he started with a small amount of money. Now he has analyzed that with more money he could have more profit out of his business. So he wants to borrow money to expand his business and better support his family.

loans.use: Purchasing more rice for greater sales.

loans.name: Parveen Ashfaq's Clothing Sales Group

texts.en:
Parveen baji is the wife of Mr. A. and lives in a small area named Bund Road of City Lahore, Pakistan. She owes a two-room brick house and has been living in it for the last 2 years. She is the mother of four children: three sons and one daughter. All of her children are enrolled in a local school in her neighborhood. Parveen baji's husband has a clothing-selling business. He has been in this business for the last 8 years. Parveen baji herself is a housewife and prefers to do household work and take care of her family. She is applying for a loan to expand her husband's business by buying more clothes.

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Nabeela baji and Mumtaz baji each want a loan to buy scrap (plastic bottles, waste papers) for their scrap businesses. Ifat baji wants a loan to repair an auto-ricksahw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Ailas baji wants a loan to buy material (cloth, thread) for her bedsheet-making business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to resell

loans.name: Anor

texts.en:
Anor is a single mother of 2 kids. She does not have a husband.

She works hard every day in order to support her family. She sells grocery goods in the markets and on the streets. Anor mostly sells goods to her neighbors.

Anor doesn't have enough money to buy more grocery goods for sale. Therefore she has decided to try to expand her small business by borrowing money. She is asking for $500 for 9 months. She promises to repay the loan in time.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery goods to sell

loans.name: Mariam's Group

texts.en:
This loan is for a small group of three members. Mariam M. is 40 years old, widowed, and sells perfume in the market. She has been selling perfume since 2006 and earns around USD $4 per day. Mariam has five children, two of them are married and other three stay home and are in school. Mariam needs a loan of USD $200 to add to her money to purchase a secondhand motorcycle to transport her perfume to sell. She is the group leader and other two are: 
1- Mrs. Ler L., a grocery seller who needs a loan of USD $200 to purchase more grocerys to sell. 
2- Mrs. Khor M.,  a fish seller. She needs a loan of USD $200 to purchase a pump for her husband to use in his business of growing vegetable. 
They all live in Slaket Commune, Battambang Province.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle

loans.name: Jumagul

texts.en: Jumagul Y. is the mother of two kids.  Unfortunately, her husband died several years ago, so she had to find a way to survive and feed her kids. First she started by selling kilograms of flour at the market.  Now she has a constant clientele who buy flour from her. But in order to keep her clients, she needs to expand her business and provide more flour. The money she gets from her business now is barely enough to feed her kids. So she decided to borrow money so that she can expand her business.

loans.use: Purchasing more flour for greater sales.

loans.name: Rup Laxmi

texts.en:
Mrs. Rup Laxmi S. is a tailor in the town of Tikhidewal, Lalitpur. She lives with her husband and two sons. Her husband works in a government office, and her sons are now studying in the higher secondary school. 

She opened her tailoring shop a year ago. Her specialty is making custom-fitted ladies dresses like the Kurta Sulwar, which are very popular with Nepali women. Before starting her own business, Mrs. S. took a 6 month training course in tailoring from a tailor shop near her home.

She plans to use the loan of Rs 10000.00 ($150.00) to buy raw materials for her tailoring work. She wants to use the shop's income to improve her standard of living and for her son's education.

loans.use: Buy tailoring materials

loans.name: Anu

texts.en:
Mrs. Anu S., 28-years-old, is a tailor in the town of Tikhidewal in Lalitpur. She opened her tailoring shop two years ago. Her specialty is making custom-fitted ladies' dresses and school uniforms for both boys and girls. She prefers to make popular dresses like Kurta Sulwar, blouses, ladies' long dresses, Makhshi and others.

Before starting her own business, Mrs. S. took a six month training course in tailoring when she was younger. Now, Mrs. S. is requesting a Rs 10000.00 loan to buy raw materials for her work. Mrs. S. lives in a single family with her husband and son. Her husband's name is Mr. Sanjay S. and he works in his own workshop. She has one son, who is studying in primary school.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for her work

loans.name: Rashma

texts.en:
Rashma M. is a resident of Tikhidewal. Tikhidewal is located in Lalitpur district. Most of the people in this area are engaged in small businesses.

Mrs. M. lives in a single-family home with her husband and two daughters. Her husband's name is Mr. Sanu Babu M., and he works in a catering shop. Both of her daughters are studying in preschool.

Mrs. M. is a grocery shopkeeper in Tikhidewal. She opened her grocery shop a few months ago in hopes of improving the living standard of her family. She sells different types of groceries in her shop, like rice, maize, paddy, noodles, and so on. Mrs. M. is requesting her first loan of Rs. 10000.00 ($150.00) to expand her business.

loans.use: Buy goods for grocery shop

loans.name: Reshma Kumari

texts.en:
Mrs. Resham Kumari M. is a single lady who is a tailor in the town of Tikhidewal in Lalitpur. She lives with her father and one brother. Her father is a farmer, and her brother is studying at a secondary school.

Before starting her own business, Mrs. M. took a 6 month training course in tailoring. She opened her tailoring shop a year ago. Her specialty is making custom-fitted ladies dresses and school uniforms for both boys and girls. She prefers to make popular dresses, like Kurta Sulwar, blouses, long ladies dresses, Makhshi, and others.

Mrs. M. is requesting a loan for Rs 10,000 ($150.00). She plans to use the loan to buy raw materials for her tailoring work.

loans.use: Buy tailoring materials

loans.name: Parbati

texts.en:
Mrs. Parbati R. M. is a tailor in the town of Tikhidewal in Lalitpur. She lives with her husband, Mr. Bhoj Bahadur, who is a farmer.

Before starting her own business, Mrs. R. M. took a 6 month training course in tailoring. She opened her tailoring shop a year ago and now also has a training center for tailoring. Her specialty is making custom-fitted ladies dresses and school uniforms for both boys and girls. She prefers to make popular dresses like Kurta Sulwar, blouses, long ladies dresses, Makhshi, and others.

Mrs. Parbati R. M. is requesting a loan of Rs 10,000 ($150.00). She plans to use the loan to buy raw materials for her tailoring work.

loans.use: Buy tailoring materials

loans.name: Semeni

texts.en:
Semeni H. M. is 32 years old and married with five children, ages three, four, nine, ten, and fourteen. Semeni has been selling spices in Zanzibar since 2007. She works every day from 8:00 am to 9:00 pm and earns a profit of approximately $15 each month.

She is now hoping to take out her first loan so that she may expand her business and increase her profit. She will use the loan to buy more spices for her shop.

loans.use: To buy more spices for her shop.

loans.name: Narmila

texts.en:
Mrs. S. lives in a single-family home with her husband and son, who is in grade three. Her husband's name is Suresh Prasad G. S. and he works in a private office. Her husband also helps her in her sandal store in the morning and evening.

Mrs. Narmila G. S. opened her sandal store four years ago. She sells different types of sandals for girls and boys. She buys the sandals from the wholesale market, Ashan Bazaar, where there is only one sandal store, so the demand is comparatively high.

Mrs. S. is requesting her first loan of Rs 10,000.00 ($150.00) to buy various types of sandals for her store.

loans.use: Buy various sandals

loans.name: Kamala

texts.en:
Mrs. Kamala R. lives in Tikhidewal, Lalitpur. She has one son and three daughters. Her son is in grade 12. Her two older daughters are studying for a BBS (Bachelor in Business Studies) degree and her youngest daughter is in grade 6. A few years ago, her husband, Bal Ram R., died. She now has sole responsibility for her 4 children.

Mrs. R. makes different types of artificial flower decorations. She trained for one month at the flower training institution. She sells her flower decorations in the local flower shop. She is requesting a loan of Rs 10,000.00 ($150.00) to buy materials for her work.

loans.use: Buy artificial flower making materials

loans.name: Nita

texts.en:
Mrs. Nita G. lives in Tikhidewal, which is located in the Lalitpur district. Most of the people in this area are engaged in small businesses, like grocery stores, small hotels, and stationery stores.

Mrs. G. lives in a joint family with her mother-in-law, brother-in-law, and husband. Her husband's name is Mr. Kishor, who went abroad 6 months ago for work.

Mrs. G. and the rest of the family members run a small restaurant. They sell different types of food, especially newari food. The demand for newari food is increasing in Tikhidewal, so Mrs. G. is requesting her first loan of Rs 10,000.00 ($150.00) to buy more food for her restaurant.

loans.use: Buy additional food for restaurant

loans.name: Malika

texts.en:
Mrs. Malika Ghirire lives in Tikhidewal, Lalitpur. She lives with her husband, mother-in-law, and brother-in-law.  Her husband's name is Mr. Arjun G. and he works in a private office. Her brother-in-law works in the Nepal army.

Mrs. G. opened a grocery shop few months ago to better the living standard of her family. Due to lack of funds, she can't buy goods for her shop. So she is asking for her first loan of Rs 10000.00 ($150 USD) to buy goods like rice, dal, noodles, and other items.

loans.use: To buys grocery goods

loans.name: Nanu

texts.en:
Mrs. Nanu S. is a beautician in Tikhidewal. She opened her beauty parlor 5 years ago. Before opening her own beauty parlor, she took a year of beauty parlor training from a training institution. Her service is for ladies. In Nepal, this is the season of festivals, so many married women, as well as unmarried women, go to beauty parlors to look good. Mrs. Nanu S. is requesting her first loan for Rs 10000.00 to buy various make-up tools for her service.

Mrs. Nanu S. lives in a joint family with her husband, father-in-law, mother-in-law and brother-in-law. Her husband’s name is Mr. Bhola Raj and he works in his own CD shop.

loans.use: To buy make-up tools

loans.name: Zubaida's Group

texts.en:
Zubaida baji is the wife of M. N. and lives in a small area named Bund Road of City Lahore, Pakistan. She owes a two-room brick house and has been living in it for the last 2 years. She is the mother of three children: two sons and one daughter. Her son is not yet school-going age. Her elder daughter is in the 6th standard. Her younger daughter is in the 3rd standard. 

Zubaida baji's husband has a barber salon in his community. He is a well-known barber in the community. He learned this skill from his father. He has been in this profession for the last 5 years. Zubaida baji herself has been running a beauty parlor for the last 10 years but she is a responsible mother. She pays attention on her children and teaches and guides them in their education. Zubaida baji is applying for a loan to buy materials (cosmetics, hair dryer) to  expand her parlor.

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Parveen baji wants a loan to buy more clothes to resell. Zareena baji wants a loan to repair her auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Rani baji wants a loan to buy material (wood, tools) for her furniture-making business. Rashida baji wants a loan to buy more fruits to resell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy material for her beauty parlor

loans.name: Nadra's Group

texts.en:
Nadra baji is a wife of Mr. S. and lives in a small area named Bund Road in the city of Lahore, Pakistan. She owns a two-room brick house and has been living in it for the last two years. She has been married for the last 10 years. Nadra baji's husband is a government employee. Nadra baji's brother lives with her and works in the jewelery business. He buys jewelry from different jewelery shops and sells it in his community. He has been in this business for the last 10 years. Nadra baji is a housewife and prefers to do household work and to take care of her family. She is applying for a loan for her brother's jewelry business so that he can expand his business and earn more money.

She is one of the six members of this group that is applying for a loan. Shakeela baji and Bilquis baji each want a loan to buy sanitary supplies for their sanitary business. Tahira baji wants a loan to buy seasonal fruits to resell. Naziran baji wants a loan to buy artificial flowers for her decorative business. Nasreen baji wants a loan to repair an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle).

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy jewelry

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Purchase clothing and cosmetics

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy shoes and slippers

loans.name: Pavel

texts.en:
Pavel is married with two children. He lives in Novomoskovsk and sells disposable bags and plastic dishware in one of the local markets. He has been in this trade for 3 years. Currently, Pavel has about $6,000 in inventory. His profit is about $800 a month.  

Pavel has passed many milestones on his road to success. He has learned to adapt with each wave of change in the market world. Today he is a stable and confident entrepreneur with many bright ideas and plans for the future. One of his current plans is to increase his turnover capital with the help of a 3,000 Grivna loan. 

Note: this is a short-term seasonal loan that will be repaid in two months.

loans.use: To purchase inventory

loans.name: Yuryi

texts.en:
Yuryi is single. He has always dreamed of being self-employed and decided to apply his practical skills to launch his business manufacturing granite products. Yuryi started this enterprise a year and a half ago. His business has grown to be a very stable and competitive enterprise offering a wide selection of items and a flexible discount system for clients. Yuryi has over $3,000 in turnover capital. His net profit is about $400 a month.

Yuryi has an entrepreneurial mind that is always alive, active, constantly calculating and always on the lookout for the next big opportunity. His business is profitable and stable. However, Yuryi would like to press on and expand it even more. Today he is requesting a loan of 5,000 Grivnas to increase his stock of raw materials for further granite work and to meet the growing demand.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials

loans.name: Fatou Niakassy

texts.fr: Fatou Niakassy S., 55 ans, mariée, 04 enfants en charge est membre du banc villageois des Ressortissantes Mpack depuis 2 ans. Elle veut un prêt pour acheter du sel, du nététou, de l’huile de palme, du miel, du piment et des diakhato et revendre. Ses revenus lui permettent d’améliorer ses conditions de vie. <b> Le prêt qu’elle sollicite sera remboursé au bout de six mois en une seule échéance. <b/>
texts.en:
Fatou Niakassy S., 55, married and raising 4 children, has been a member of the village bank of Ressortissantes Mpack for 2 years. She wants a loan to buy salt, nététou (an edible paste made from tree leaves), palm oil, honey, hot peppers, etc. for re-sale. Her income permits her to improve her living conditions. The loan that she is requesting will be reimbursed in one single repayment at the end of 6 months.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buying and selling vegetables and foodstuffs

loans.name: Larisa

texts.en:
Larisa is divorced with two children. She lives in her home town of Ordzhonikidze and sells footwear in the central marketplace there. She has been in this trade for 13 years. Larisa currently has over $5,000 in turnover capital, and her net profit is little over $600.

Larisa's business has always boasted a nice variety of merchandise, resulting in high demand. She is requesting a loan of 2500 Grivna to help her generate additional income and keep her sales stable. Larisa has a long history of good credit. She is known as an entrepreneur of integrity. We believe her good record and honest approach to business will guarantee prompt loan repayment.

Note: This is a short-term seasonal loan that will be repaid in two months.

loans.use: To increase her footwear inventory

loans.name: Olga

texts.en:
Olga is a married mom of two grown kids and a successful entrepreneur, too. She sells women's underwear and night gowns in one of the local markets called "Sigma-sport." Olga has assorted merchandise and always tries to introduce unique items to her selection of products to keep a stable position in an atmosphere of fierce competition in the market.

Olga has been in this business for 10 years. Presently, she has over $4,000 invested in inventory. Her gross income is about $2,000. Olga is very energetic. She finds time for family, business, personal growth and floral design, which is one of her numerous hobbies. This time she is requesting a 2,500 Grivna loan to increase her working capital.

loans.use: Increase working capital

loans.name: Irina

texts.en:
Irina operates a small business selling children's clothes in Nikolaev, Ukraine. She has an attractively arranged little outdoor kiosk at the Ekur market in Nikolaev where she carries all sorts of necessary items for babies and kids. Irina has been in business for about two years and has developed a stable, profitable enterprise based on products that are always in demand. Her business has become the main source of income for her, her husband Maxim and 6-year-old daughter. In a typical month she makes around $1,000 in income.

Irina's business is growing. She has requested a loan of 2000 Grivnas, $375, to increase her working capital and help boost the further development of her business.

Note: this is a short term seasonal loan that will be repaid in two months.

loans.use: To increase the variety of products

loans.name: Gerardo

texts.es:
Gerardo inició el negocio por ser un oficio que aprendió desde joven ya que el deseaba tener un empleo y aprender un oficio ya que no pudo continuar con sus estudios debido a razones económicas, es por esto que hace 14 años comenzó de ayudante de albañil y ahora es maestro albañil por lo que el realiza contratos en donde puedo tener mas utilidad y ofrecerles mejor calidad de vida a sus tres pequeños hijos de 5, 3 y 1 año.

El necesita un préstamo por US $400 que pagara en 6 meses para comprar herramienta que requiere en su trabajo diario. Con tu apoyo Gerardo saldrá adelante.
texts.en:
Gerardo began his business because this is a trade that he learned when he was young. He desired to have a job and learn a trade, because he could not continue with his studies due to economic reasons. This is why fourteen years ago he began as a masonry apprentice and now he is a master mason. He does his own contracts now so he can offer a better quality of life to his three little children, who are one, three, and five years old. He needs a loan for $400, which he will pay back in six months, to buy tools that he requires in his daily jobs. With your support Gerardo will come out on top.

Translated from Spanish by Jay Osborne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buy tools

loans.name: Maria Oralia

texts.es:
Oralia inició su negocio ya que le gusta la repostería y además tendría la oportunidad de tener una actividad productiva que le permitiera generar un ingreso ya que ella es viuda y necesitaba un ingreso extra además de su pensión. Comenzó hace 7 años a elaborar galletas finas sobre pedido con sus conocidos, quienes la fueron recomendando y logro adquirir mas clientes hasta la fecha, que le va muy bien con su negocio.

Ella necesita un préstamo por US $200 que pagara en 6 meses para comprar moldes y charolas para la elaboración de sus galletas. Con tu apoyo Oralia saldrá adelante!!.
texts.en:
Oralia began her business because she likes baking and it was an opportunity to have a productive activity that will generate an income since she is a window and needs an extra income besides her pension. She began seven years ago creating fancy cookies for orders from people she knew; they were recommending her to others and she acquired more clients and now she's doing very well with her business. She needs a loan for $200, which she will pay back in six months, to buy baking pans and trays to prepare her cookies. With your support, Oralia will come out on top!

Translated from Spanish by Jay Osborne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buy baking pans and trays

loans.name: Blanca Judith

texts.es: Blanca Judith está solicitando su crédito para terminar de repellar las paredes de su casa. Labora desde hace 10 años como docente de Educación primaria, primeramente inició dando clases en la colonia Naciones Unidas a unos 35 kilometros de Nueva Guinea, hasta este año la trasladaron a dar clases en la zona Urbana de Nueva Guinea. Judith es madre de un niño de 5 añitos de edad, actualmente lo tiene estudiando pre escolar en el mismo colegio que ella trabaja. Blanca se caracteriza por ser una buena maestra, responsable , honesta y muy trabajadora, a pesar que ella no tiene la ayuda del padre de su hijo es una mujer que lucha para que a su hijo no le falte nada, su sueño es seguir estudiando, ir mejorando su vivienda con cada crédito otorgado por AFODENIC, salud para su familia y estabilidad laboral.
texts.en:
Blanca Judith is requesting her loan so she can finish plastering the walls in her house. She has worked for the past ten years as a primary school teacher. She first started teaching classes in the United Nations colony, about 35 kilometers from New Guinea. Judith is the mother of one 5-year old son who she has studying in pre-school at the same school where she works. Blanca is characterized by being a good teacher, responsible, honest, and very hard-working despite the fact that she doesn’t have help from her child’s father. She is a woman who fights so that her son does not want for anything. Her dreams are to continue her studies, to improve her home with each loan granted by AFODENIC, health for her family and stable employment.


Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To plaster the walls in her house.

loans.name: Aurora Elena

texts.es:
La señora Aurora C. se dedica al negocio de pulpería desde hace 20 largos años siendo este el único sustento de su humilde hogar de habitación. Desde que inició ha venido atravesando situaciones adversas por lo que ha duplicado sus esfuerzos en el negocio.

La necesidad qeu ella atraviesa en estos momentos es que debe adquirir su mercadería y para esto acude a Ceprodel con el fin de obtener un crédito para obtener la mercadería y de esta forma comercializarla.
texts.en:
Aurora C. has dedicated herself to her general store business for twenty long years, as it was the only means of support for her humble home. Since she started, she has gone through some difficult times for which she has duplicated her efforts related to her enterprise.

Her current need is to acquire merchandise, for which she turns to Ceprodel with the aim of obtaining a loan so she can supply her store and sell her products.


Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of merchandise.

loans.name: Maira Yuliza

texts.es:
La señora Maira Yuliza L. V. tiene 30 años de edad, pertenece al Banco Comunal Hilos de Plata II, es madre soltera y vive en la Av. Nuevo Trujillo Mz B lote 9 Manuel Arévalo, distrito de Huanchaco, provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad, Perú. Estudió secundaria completa, viajó a Chile donde quería seguir estudiando y trabajando, pero tuvo un hijo.
Actualmente hace almuerzos para dejarlos en las instituciones que le solicitan, prepara también dietas y cada 15 días hace parrilladas. Tiene visión de negocio porque es muy solicitada por la preparación de dietas ya que ninguna otra persona de la zona lo elabora.
Con este primer préstamo de 300 soles, el cual será cancelado en 4 cuotas compró una olla arrocera de tamaño grande.
Con este crédito de 300 soles, el cual será cancelado en 4 cuotas, comprará arroz y aceite.
Maira sueña con tener un restaurant grande que sea muy concurrido.
texts.en:
Maira Yuliza L. V. is 30 years old and belongs to the “Hilos de Plata II” (Silver Threads II) communal bank. She is a single mother and she lives on Nuevo Trujillo Avenue, Block B, Lot 9 Manuel Arévalo, in the Huanchaco district of Trujillo province, La Libertad department, Peru. She completed high school, and traveled to Chile, where she wanted to continue studying and working, but she had a child. She now makes lunches and takes them to the institutions that request them. She also makes special order foods and does a barbeque every 15 days. She has a vision for business because she is very sought after for special order foods, since no one else in the area makes them. With her first loan of 300 soles, which will repaid in 4 payments, she bought a large rice cooker. With this loan of 300 soles, which she will repay in 4 payments, she will buy rice and cooking oil. Maira dreams of having a big restaurant that will have many customers.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: She will buy rice and cooking oil.

loans.name: Dora María

texts.es:
La señora Rosa Arbizú se dedica al negocio de pulpería el cual atiende en su casa de habitación en el municipio de Telica de la ciudad de León.

Ella actualmente se ha destacado por ser muy trabajadora y además por atender muy amablemente a los clientes. También se ha destacado por vender deliciosos refrescos naturales preparados por ella misma. La razón por la que ha solicitado el crédito es para comprar la materia prima para la elaboración de los refrescos y además para la compra de mercadería para la pulpería.
texts.en:
Rosa Arbizu's business is a convenience store that she runs from her home, located in the municipality of Telica in the city of Leon.

She has proved to herself to be very hard working and in she attends her clients very kindly. She has also started to sell delicious fresh juices that she herself prepares. The reason for requesting a loan is to purchase ingredients to make her juices and to purchase merchandise to restock her convenience store.


Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase merchandise.

loans.name: Manuela Rosa

texts.es:
La señora Manuela Rosa tiene 53 años de edad, pertenece al Banco Comunal Hilas de Plata y vive en Mz A8 lote 51 de Manuel Arévalo, distrito de La Esperanza, provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad, Perú. Estudió hasta el tercer año de primaria y no continuó estudiando porque sus padres no quisieron apoyarla.
Se casó a los 20 años con Víctor Espejo y tuvo 7 hijos, de los cuales 3 son estudiantes y depende económicamente de ella.
Empezó vendiendo ceviche y luego incrementó la venta con tallarín. A sus comensales les gusta la sazón que tiene Manuelita, así la llaman cariñosamente los que la conocen, por lo que incrementó más la venta con el caldo de carne, de gallina, de cabeza. Los sábado y domingo elabora menú y todos comentan que es la mejor cocinera de la zona. Tiene un toldo ambulante fuera del Mercado Acomar.
Con el primer préstamo de 300 soles cancelado en 4 cuotas lo tomó como capital para vender en la noche cerca de su domicilio, pero no le dio resultado y lo dejó y todo su capital lo invirtió en los almuerzos.
Con este crédito de 500 soles, el cual será cancelado en 4 cuotas, implementará su negocio y cambiará el toldo con uno de mejor material al que tiene actualmente.
Manuelita sueña con tener un restaurant más céntrico.
texts.en:
Manuela Rosa is 53 years old and is a member of the Hilas de Plata Communal Bank in the Mz A8 lot 51 of Manuel Arévalo, in the district of La Esperanza, province of Trujillo, department of La Libertad, Perú. She studied through the third year of primary school and did not continue because her parents did not want to support her. She married Víctor Espejo at the age of 20 and had 7 children, 3 of whom are students and depend on her financially. She began selling ceviche and later augmented her business with the sale of noodles. Manuelita’s regular customers like her seasonings, and those who know her refer to her affectionately. She has also increased her business with the sale of various soups and broths. Saturdays and Sundays, she creates her menu and everyone comments that she is the best cook in the area. She has a mobile awning outside of the Acomar Market. With her first loan of 300 soles, which was repaid in 4 payments, she began selling at night near her home. However, this did not succeed and she left it to invest all of her capital in lunch sales. With the requested loan of 500 soles, to be repaid in four payments, she will outfit her business and change her awning to one made with better material. Manuelita dreams of having a more centrally located restaurant.

Translated from Spanish by Kara Gibson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To outfit her business and replace an awning with one of better quality.

loans.name: Manuela Rosa

texts.es:
La  señora Manuela Rosa tiene 46 años, pertenece al Banco Comunal Mujeres Valerosas II y vive en la calle Castelli 785, distrito La Esperanza Alta,  provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad, Perú. Estudió hasta primer año de secundaria, pero manifiesta que no le gustaba estudiar y no lo hizo. Se casó a los 19 años y se separó con una hija. Actualmente ayuda a su hija a criar su pequeño bebé. Vende cerveza, gaseosa, golosina, víveres y ropa interior. Su negocio se ubica en su domicilio.
Con su primer crédito de 300 soles, el cual devolvió en 4 cuotas, incrementó su negocio y compró algunas cosas que necesitaba.
Con este crédito de 800 soles, el cual será cancelado en 6 cuotas, piensa comprar cerveza e invertir en gaseosa, golosinas y vino.
El sueño de toda su vida es tener su casa propia, ya que donde vive actualmente es casa de sus padres.
texts.en:
Manuela Rosa is 46 years old and a member of the Valiant Women II Communal Bank. She lives at 785 Catelli Street in the La Esperanza District, Trujillo Province, Department of La Libertad, Perú. She attended school up until the first year of secondary school, but it was obvious that she did not like to study and that she did not do it. She married at the age of 19 and is now separated with one daughter. At the moment, she helps her daughter to take care of her small baby. She sells beer, sodas, snacks, food and underwear. Her business is situated in her home. With her first loan of 300 soles, which was repaid in 4 installments, she expanded her business and bought some things she needed. With the currently requested loan of 800 soles, which is to be repaid in 6 installments, she will buy beer and also invest in soda, snacks and wine. Her life’s dream is to have her own house as she currently lives in the home of her parents.

Translated from Spanish by Kara Gibson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy beer, sodas, snacks and wine.

loans.name: Martina

texts.es: Doña Martina está solicitando su crédito para invertirlo en mejora de su vivienda (construcción de una habitación),  esta clienta tiene dos hijos,  el mayor de  9  años estudia su 4to grado y la niña menor estudia 1er grado de educación primaria,  esta clienta no sólo se dedica a enseñar sino que tambien por las tardes  trabaja de la mano con su marido  en el negocio que tienen en el mercado municipal de Nueva Guinea, para así mejorar las condiciones de vida de ella y su familia,  Martina actualmente está estudiando una licenciatura en la Universidad URACAN, tiene muchos deseos de superación profesional y personal. En el colegio donde ella labora es muy querida por sus alumnos, padres de familia y docentes por ser una mujer muy humilde pero bien responsable con sus deberes.  Su sueño es  tener una casa bonita como todo cuidadano desea con  todas las condiciones, tener salud, trabajo y que su hijos estudien para que lleguen hacer personas de bien.
texts.en:
Martina is requesting a loan to invest in improving her house by constructing a new room. She has two children, the older of whom is 9 and studies in the 4th grade, while his younger sister is in the first grade of primary school. Martina is not only dedicated to teaching, but she also works with her husband in the afternoons doing manual labor for their business in the municipal market of New Guinea. To improve living conditions for herself and for her family, Martina is currently studying for a degree at the URACAN University. She has tremendous personal and professional goals. In the high school where she works, she is affectionately thought of by her students, their parents and administration for being humble and very responsible with her duties. Her dream is to have a pretty house like those in the city. She wants to be healthy, to work, and to have her children study so that they become good citizens and good people.

Translated from Spanish by Kara Gibson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Construction of a room.

loans.name: José Rodrigo

texts.es:
En el municipio de Telica de la ciudad de León el señor José B. desde hace 25 años se dedica al negocio de elaboración de artesanías las cuales las elabora con el material de trabajo como es barro, arena y leña.

El señor B. tiene sus metas de convertirse en un gran comerciante y por este motivo es que se esfuerza a diario en el negocio. Por esto eso es que hoy en día acude a Ceprodel para solicitar un crédito con el cual comprar los materiales de trabajo y así continuar en el negocio que tanto requiere de inversión en este momento.
texts.en:
For 25 years, José B. has worked in the municipality of Telica in the city of León as an artisan, designing crafts with mud, sand and firewood as his work materials. Mr. B.'s goal is to become a sizeable retailer, and it is with this objective in mind that he strives daily in his business. He approached Kiva field partner Ceprodel to request a loan with which to buy work materials and thereby sustain the business that requires so much investment at this time.

Translated from Spanish by Kara Gibson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of work materials.

loans.name: Margarita Dorliza

texts.es:
La señora Margarita Dorliza tiene 28 años de edad, pertenece al Banco Comunal San Luis y vive en el barrio Los Pinos 070 del caserío Motil, distrito de Agallpampa, provincia de Otuzco, La Libertad, Perú.
Estudió primaria completa, pero no continuó estudiando porque sus padres fallecieron y no tenia quien la apoye.
Se caso con el señor William Rojas y tienen 4 hijos que aún son estudiantes.
Su negocio consiste en comprar, cuyes, cerdos, conejos, patos, que luego los vende ya sea en carne o vivos, pero como no es todos los días, ha incrementado su negocio con la venta de golosinas y gaseosa al paso, todas sus actividades las realiza en su casa.
Su primer préstamo fue de 300 soles, el cual devolvió en 4 cuotas. Con dicho monto inició su negocio, es por eso que vive eternamente agradecida de Manuela Ramos porque le brindó apoyo en el momento más necesitado.
Con este crédito de 800 soles, el cual será cancelado en 6 cuotas, piensa comprar animales e incursionar en la venta de leña.
Sueña con tener un gran negocio mayorista.
texts.en:
Margarita Dorliza is 28 years old and a member of the San Luis Communal Bank. She lives in the Los Pinos neighborhood, in the small village of Motil, located in the Agallpampa District, Province of Otuzco, in La Libertad, Perú. She completed primary school but could not continue on because her parents passed away and there was no one to support her. She married William Rojas and has 4 children who are still students. Her business consists of buying guinea pigs, pigs, rabbits, and ducks, that she later sells alive or as meat. As this is not something she does every day, she has expanded her business by selling snacks and sodas on the side. All of her business activities are conducted from her home. Her first loan was for 300 soles, repaid in 4 installments. With this amount, she started her business. For this reason, she is eternally grateful to Kiva field partner Manuela Ramos, who offered support to her when she needed it most. With the currently requested loan of 800 soles, which is to be repaid in 8 installments, she will buy animals and begin selling firewood. She dreams of having a large wholesale business.

Translated from Spanish by Kara Gibson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy animals and invest in firewood sales.

loans.name: Wilson Antonio

texts.es: El Señor Wilson está solicitando su crédito para invertirlo en  mejora de su vivienda como es construcción de una habitación, labora como docente en la Universidad URACCAN en la zona Urbana de  Nueva Guinea desde  hace 15 años, actualmente está estudiando una licenciatura en la misma universidad URACCAN recinto Nueva Guinea, se caracteriza por ser humilde, responsable, honesto y con muncho deseos de superación personal y profesional, tiene una hija de 4 añitos, viven en el barrio Linda Vista de Nueva Guinea, su esposa  trabaja para una empresa comercializadora de electrodomésticos, ambos comparten los gastos familiares, su sueño es tener estabilidad laboral, una vivienda bonita y que su hija estudie para que sea una persona de bien.
texts.en:
Mr. Wilson is requesting this loan to invest in home improvement in the form of building a new room. He has worked as a docent in the urban zone of New Guinea for 15 years for URACCAN University, where he is currently studying to obtain a degree. He is humble, responsible, and honest, with a great desire to improve personally and professionally. He has a little 4-year-old daughter, and they all live in the Linda Vista neighborhood of New Guinea. His wife works for a marketing company of electric home appliances; both he and his wife share normal expenses. His dream is to have working stability and a nice home, and to have his daughter go to school to have a better life.

Translated from Spanish by Kara Gibson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Construction of a room

loans.name: Margarita Macaela

texts.es:
La señora Margarita Micaela tiene 61 años, es la presidenta de su Banco Comunal Mujeres Valerosas II y vive en la calle Pittion 916, distrito La Esperanza Alta, provincia de Trujillo, departamento La Libertad, Perú. Estudió hasta tercero de secundaria, pero ya no continuó estudiando por falta de recursos económicos. Se casó con el señor Miro Briceño Benites y tienen 9 hijos, de los cuales dos (de 19 y 16 años ) aún estudian y dependen de ellos.
Gracias a su esposo aprendió a elaborar calzado y actualmente trabaja  conjuntamente con él y ya no pagan operarios. Es Margarita quien coloca el calzado en los diferentes puestos de venta y ofrece ante la clientela modelos por catálogo.
Con el primer préstamo de 300 soles, el cual devolvió en 4 cuotas, lo utilizó para completar y comprar material.
Con este crédito de 1,000, el cual será cancelado en 6 cuotas, piensa comprar pegamento, micro poroso y neo lid (materiales para calzado).
Sueña con viajar al extranjero para exponer su calzado.
texts.en:
Margarita Micaela is 61 years old and is the president of the Valient Women II Communal Bank. She lives at 916 Pittion Street in the District of La Esperanza Alta, province of Trujillo, department of La Libertad, Perú. She went to school through the third year of secondary school, but could not continue for lack of economic resources. She married Miro Briceño Benites with whom she has 9 children, two of whom (ages 16 and 19) still live with them and are dependants. Thanks to her husband she learned to make footwear and at the moment she works jointly with him and no longer contracts workers. Margarita is the one who positions the footwear for sale and offers the customer models from the catalogue. The first loan of 300 soles, which was repaid in 4 installments, was used to buy materials. With the requested loan of 1,000 soles, which will be repaid in 6 installments, she intends to buy glue, micro porous material and neon combat material (material for footwear). She dreams about traveling to foreign places to exhibit her footwear.

Translated from Spanish by Kara Gibson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of glue and other materials for shoe making.

loans.name: Margarita

texts.es:
La señora Margarita R. B. tiene 34 años de edad, pertenece al Banco Comunal San Luis, al Vaso de leche y al Comedor Popular. Vive en el barrio Las Flores s/n del caserío de Motil, distrito de Agallpampa, provincia de Otuzco, departamento de La Libertad, Perú.
Curso primaria completa y no continuó estudiando debido a la  falta de apoyo de sus padres. Se casó a los 18 años con Aquelino Haro y tienen 4 hijos que aún son estudiantes.
Empezó su negocio comprando pescado y galletas en Trujillo, pero debido  a que el pescado se malogra rápidamente, adoptó por vender abarrotes en una pequeña bodega, sin embargo sigue comprando pescado, pero en menor cantidad. Su trabajo lo realiza en su casa.
Con su primer préstamo de 300 soles, el cual devolvió en 4 cuotas, compró abarrotes para su negocio. 
Con este crédito de 300 soles, el cual será cancelado en 4 cuotas,  comprará arroz por sacos.
Margarita sueña con tener una gran tienda.
texts.en:
Mrs. Maragarita R. B. is 34 years old, belongs to the community bank of San Luis. She lives in the Flowers neighborhood in the Agallpampa district in the Otuzco province in Peru. She didn’t finished school because she didn’t have her parents’ support. She got married when she was 18 years old and has 4 children who are in school. She started her business buying fish and cookies in Trujillo, but because fish spoils quickly, she decided to sell grocery store supplies and keep on buying fish in smaller quantities. She works at home. With her first loan of 300 soles, which she returned in 4 payments, she bought supplies for her business. With the new credit of 300 soles, which will be paid in 4 quotes, she will buy rice at wholesale prices. Margarita dreams on having a big store.

Translated from Spanish by Nina Delgado, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sacks of rice

loans.name: María Isabel

texts.es:
La señora María Isabel tiene 37 años, pertenece al Banco Comunal Hilos de Plata II y vive en la Av. Nuevo Trujillo Mz B lote 9-II, distrito de Huanchaco, provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad, Perú.
Terminó la educación secundaria y continuó estudiando computación, pero se comprometió con el señor Santos Ambrosio Díaz con el que tiene dos hijos, un varón y una mujer, son gemelos.
La invitaron a vender productos de belleza y le rindió económicamente muy bien. Continua en este negocio y se ha convertido en una excelente vendedora. Cuando la invitaron a participar en el banco comunal tenía un poco de desconfianza, pero le sirvió de mucho. Actualmente está muy agradecida de Manuela Ramos.
Con el primer crédito de 300 soles, el cual canceló en 4 cuotas, compró productos para tenerlo en stock.
Con este crédito de 500 soles, el cual será cancelado en 4 cuotas, comprará productos para tenerlo en stock.
Marita, como todos la llaman, sueña con tener un mini mercado muy surtido.
texts.en:
Mrs. Maria Isabel is 37 years old and belongs to the community bank Hilos de Plata II and lives at Av. Nuevo Trujillo Mz B lote 9-II, district of Huanchaco, province of Trujillo, department of Liberty in Peru. She finished school and studied computers, but got engaged with Mr. Santos Ambrosio Diaz and they have now twins, a boy and a girl. She was invited to sell beauty products and it worked out very well for her. She continued this business and turned into an excellent saleswoman. When she was invited to participate on a community bank she wasn’t sure about it, but now she is very grateful. With her first loan of 300 soles that she paid in 4 quotes she bought products to increase her stock. With the current loan of 500 soles that will be paid in 4 quotes she will also invest on increasing her inventory. Marita, as everyone calls her, dreams on having a very well stocked mini-market.

Translated from Spanish by Nina Delgado, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: She will buy beauty products.

loans.name: María Isabel

texts.es:
La señora María Isabel tiene 51 años de edad, pertenece al Banco Comunal Mujeres al Progreso y vive en la Mz 22 lote 5 del sector Víctor Raúl II etapa Barrio 2 A, distrito del Porvenir, provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad, Perú.
Estudió hasta el tercer año de primaria, no continuó estudiando porque empezó a trabajar debido a los escasos recursos económicos.
Tuvo su primer hija a los catorce años y su pareja falleció, se volvió a casar a los 15 años con Isidro Vaca con quien tiene 2 hijas, en total tiene tres hijas, pero ninguna dependen de ella porque cada una tiene su compromiso.
Actualmente María Isabel vende comida, pero también está incursionando en la compra y venta de chatarra.
